The mystery of why flying saucers are the dominant shape in UFO reports was addressed by Martin Kottmeyer, who discovered that Kenneth Arnold’s initial sighting in 1947 was misinterpreted. Arnold’s description of the objects’ motion, rather than their shape, led to the “flying saucer” label. This mistake shaped the UFO phenomenon for decades, influencing film imagery, saucer photography, UFO illustration, contactee tales, and abduction experiences. Kottmeyer’s findings, first reported in 1988, suggest a cultural origin for the flying saucer phenomenon. The principal counterargument is that flying saucers were seen before Kenneth Arnold’s story, but Kottmeyer argues that the dominance of the saucer shape after 1947 is the key issue.

Flaps of Flying Phantoms 🔗

Early researchers attempted to correlate UFO flaps with Mars’ proximity, but these predictions failed. British researchers shifted focus to pre-1947 “waves,” examining social, religious, political, and scientific backgrounds. Roger Sandell’s work on a 1905 Welsh UFO outbreak revealed odd facets and high strangeness material. Nigel Watson reported on a 1909 panic involving German airships spying on Britain. Phantom airship flaps were catalogued from various locations, involving cigar-shaped craft and rumors of foreign spies. By the 1930s, phantom airships were replaced by phantom aeroplanes. Researchers have experimented with variations in these explanations, such as the 1905 Wales flap occurring during a time of social change. Researchers generally reject explanations involving mass hysteria, preferring to discuss flaps as collective delusions maintained by rumor and gossip.

The Modern Myth of Jung 🔗

Carl Gustav Jung’s essay Flying Saucers: A Modern Myth of Things Seen in the Skies is considered a foundational work for the PSH. Jung’s use of synchronicity has also led some to see him as a proponent of paranormal explanations. While Jung acknowledged the possibility of some UFOs being physical objects, he clarified that he was uncommitted on the issue of their reality. He expressed concern that news affirming the existence of UFOs was more welcome than skepticism.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychosocial_hypothesis

item.title: Psychosocial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Psychosocial Hypothesis in Ufology 🔗

The psychosocial hypothesis (PSH) in ufology suggests that some UFO reports are best explained by psychological or social factors rather than extraterrestrial origins. It contrasts with the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH) and is favored by UFO researchers in the UK and France. Proponents view UFOs as an interesting subject for study, even with skepticism.

Origin 🔗

The term “psychosocial hypothesis” gained prominence in English UFO literature in 1984, influenced by French UFO controversies sparked by Michel Monnerie’s challenge to the ETH. Magonia magazine played a key role in popularizing the term. Peter Rogerson’s adoption of the term marked a shift away from paranormal explanations towards normal psychological processes influenced by cultural myths and social conditioning. Writers associated with Magonia had been exploring alternatives to the ETH since 1968, driven by the belief that it failed to account for high strangeness cases. Roger Sandell’s research on a 1905 Welsh UFO wave led him to conclude that UFO reports were part of a larger complex of ghost stories and religious visions. Peter Rogerson advocated for a search for historical antecedents of UFO rumors and the social factors driving UFO flaps and social panics, noting a relationship between UFO waves and times of radical social change.

Science Fiction Aspects of the UFO Mythos 🔗

Bertrand Méheust’s study of science fiction parallels to UFO mythology revealed numerous similarities between UFO experience narratives and pre-1947 science fiction literature. These parallels include wondrous effects like invisible force-fields, teleportation, and engine-stopping rays, as well as humanoid motives for visiting Earth. Michel Monnerie integrated Meheust’s study into his historical critique of UFO mythology. Michel Meurger expanded Meheust’s thesis with a compendium of parallels. Jacques Vallee noted electromagnetic effects associated with UFOs in earlier fiction. Researchers have explored the cultural backstories to various alien types, including Grays, insectoids, and reptoids.

The Saucer Rumor 🔗

The psychosocial approach helped solve the mystery of why flying saucers are the dominant shape in UFO reports. Martin Kottmeyer discovered that the “flying saucer” label originated from a misinterpretation of Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting. Arnold described the objects’ motion as erratic, “like a saucer if you skip it across the water,” but the reporter misinterpreted this as describing the objects’ shape. This mistake shaped the UFO phenomenon for decades, influencing film imagery, saucer photography, UFO illustration, contactee tales, and abduction experiences.

Flaps of Flying Phantoms 🔗

Early researchers attempted to correlate UFO flaps with Mars’ proximity, but these predictions failed. British researchers shifted focus to pre-1947 “waves,” examining social, religious, political, and scientific backgrounds. Nigel Watson researched a March–May 1909 panic involving German airships spying on Britain. Phantom airship flaps were cataloged in various locations, often accompanied by rumors of foreign spies. By the 1930s, phantom airships were replaced by phantom aeroplanes. Researchers have experimented with variations in these explanations, such as the 1905 Wales flap occurring during a time of rapid social change. Researchers generally reject explanations involving mass hysteria, preferring to discuss flaps as collective delusions maintained by rumor and gossip.

The Modern Myth of Jung 🔗

Carl Gustav Jung’s essay Flying Saucers: A Modern Myth of Things Seen in the Skies is considered a foundational work of the PSH. While some argue that Jung also considered the ETH, Jung himself refuted claims that he believed UFOs were physically real. He emphasized the psychological significance of the UFO phenomenon, regardless of its objective reality.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychosocial_UFO_hypothesis

item.title: Extraterrestrials in fiction
item.description:
Fictional Depictions of Extraterrestrial Life 🔗

This article discusses extraterrestrials as they are portrayed in works of fiction, distinguishing them from alleged real-life encounters. It includes a link to a separate article listing alleged extraterrestrial beings. A banner at the top indicates that the article relies heavily on a limited number of sources and needs more citations.

History 🔗

This section explores the historical evolution of extraterrestrial depictions in fiction, starting from antiquity and progressing through modern times.

Antiquity 🔗

This subsection covers early depictions of extraterrestrials, beginning with Lucian’s 2nd-century satire True History, where the protagonist visits the Moon and finds it inhabited by warring factions. It emphasizes how early concepts of extraterrestrials were tied to the development of astronomy and the understanding of celestial objects as physical entities. Early depictions often portrayed aliens as human-like, as exemplified by Voltaire’s Micromégas and works by Johannes Kepler, Francis Godwin, and Cyrano de Bergerac.

Early 20th Century 🔗

This section discusses the impact of Charles Darwin’s On the Origin of Species on alien depictions, leading to the creation of non-humanoid aliens in fiction. Camille Flammarion’s works are mentioned as early examples of genuinely alien lifeforms. The section also highlights H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds and The First Men in the Moon as influential works that explored the implications of evolution and alien civilizations. The rise of pulp magazines and their role in popularizing science fiction with various alien tropes are also discussed, including the common use of Martians, Venusians, and other Solar System inhabitants. Stanley G. Weinbaum’s A Martian Odyssey is noted for its unique Martian ecosystem.

Modern Times 🔗

This section covers the evolution of alien depictions in more recent times. It mentions The Eternaut by Héctor Germán Oesterheld, an Argentine work that critiques imperialism and colonialism through an alien invasion of Buenos Aires. The Barney and Betty Hill incident is discussed as a pivotal event that popularized the “grey alien” archetype. The influence of TV and films, particularly Star Trek, Star Wars, and Alien, is highlighted, noting the trend towards human-like aliens due to budgetary constraints. The section concludes by mentioning the impact of computer-generated imagery (CGI) on creating more diverse and bizarre alien lifeforms.

Types 🔗

This section categorizes the various ways extraterrestrials are portrayed in fiction. It discusses differences in intelligence levels, biological forms (humanoid, Earth-species-like, or bizarre), and attitudes towards humanity (hostile, friendly, or indifferent). It also mentions that some extraterrestrials in fiction originate from unexplored areas of Earth, such as the sea, sky, underground, or other dimensions.

See Also 🔗

This section provides a list of related Wikipedia articles, including:

  • Parasites in fiction
  • List of fictional extraterrestrials
  • List of films featuring extraterrestrials
  • List of humanoid aliens
  • Mars in fiction
  • First contact (science fiction)

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, journal articles, and online resources.

Bibliography 🔗

This section lists additional books related to the topic of extraterrestrials in fiction.

Further Reading 🔗

This section provides a list of additional resources for readers interested in learning more about the topic, including books and articles.

External Links 🔗

This section contains a link to an external website with additional information on the use of aliens as metaphors in fiction.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_life_in_popular_culture

item.title: Alien invasion
item.description:
Alien Invasion 🔗

Alien invasion, also known as space invasion, is a prevalent theme in science fiction stories and films. It involves extraterrestrial lifeforms invading Earth with various motives, such as exterminating or enslaving humanity, harvesting humans for food, stealing resources, or destroying the planet. This theme is a subgenre of invasion literature, popularized by H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds, and is a type of first contact science fiction. Experts consider an actual alien invasion unlikely due to the immense costs involved.

Origins 🔗

This section discusses the origins of the alien invasion theme in fiction. H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds (1898) is considered the seminal alien invasion story, establishing themes like first contact and interplanetary war. However, earlier stories exist, such as Robert Potter’s The Germ Growers (1892), which features a covert alien invasion. The section also mentions Wells’ proposed guerrilla war scenario in The War of the Worlds. Garrett P. Serviss’ Edison’s Conquest of Mars, an unauthorized sequel to The War of the Worlds, depicts Thomas Edison leading a counterattack on Mars. The reprinting of The War of the Worlds in the United States in 1927 coincided with the Golden Age of Science Fiction. John W. Campbell and other science fiction writers, including Isaac Asimov, Arthur C. Clarke, Clifford D. Simak, and Robert A. Heinlein, further developed the theme.

Variations 🔗

This section explores different variations of the alien invasion theme.

Alien Infiltration 🔗

This variation involves invaders taking human form and infiltrating society, even taking control of command positions. Their goal may be to take over the world or prepare for a full-scale invasion. This theme reflects Cold War fears of communist infiltration. The Reptilian conspiracy theory is mentioned as a real-world belief in covert alien infiltration.

Beneficial Alien Invasion 🔗

This variation presents aliens colonizing Earth to “civilize” humanity or secretly aiding humans to prevent self-destruction. Henry Slesar’s The Delegate from Venus is mentioned. Examples include Klaatu and Gort in The Day the Earth Stood Still, Gene Roddenberry’s The Questor Tapes and Star Trek episode “Assignment: Earth”, Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End, Crest of the Stars, the film Arrival, and David Brin’s Uplift Universe series.

Invasion by Humans 🔗

This variation reverses the roles, with humans invading or attacking extraterrestrial lifeforms. Examples include the short story Sentry, the video game Phantasy Star II, The Martian Chronicles by Ray Bradbury, the Imperium of Man in the Warhammer 40,000 universe, Invaders from Earth by Robert Silverberg, Ender’s Game by Orson Scott Card, and the movies Battle for Terra, Planet 51, and Avatar.

Feasibility 🔗

This section discusses the feasibility of an actual alien invasion. Seth Shostak of the SETI Institute believes it’s unlikely due to resource availability and the likelihood of initial contact being through robots. David Morrison of NASA-Ames Research Center suggests first contact would be via radio communication.

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics, including interplanetary contamination, potential cultural impact of extraterrestrial contact, space colonization, UFO religion, The Kraken Wakes, list of films featuring space stations, and the Wow! signal.

References 🔗

This section lists the references used in the article, providing sources for the information presented.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_invasion

item.title: Malmstrom UFO incident
item.description:
Malmstrom UFO Incident 🔗

This article discusses the alleged Malmstrom UFO incident, focusing on claims that a UFO sighting was connected to a weapons failure at a nuclear missile complex in Montana in 1967. It presents claims made by retired Air Force personnel, skeptical counterarguments, and the incident’s coverage in media.

1967 Missile Complex Malfunction 🔗

This section details the 1967 incident at the Echo Flight missile complex, located between Hilger and Winifred, Montana, and operated by personnel from Malmstrom Air Force Base. On March 16, 1967, all sites in Echo Flight experienced a shutdown with “No-Go” indications, causing all launch facilities to lose strategic alert nearly simultaneously. An Air Force report mentioned rumors of UFOs around the area but stated they were disproven. A Mobile Strike Team reported no unusual activity or sightings. The malfunction, termed the “Echo Flight Incident,” was resolved within a day by maintenance crews.

Public Claims by Robert Salas 🔗

This section focuses on the claims made by Robert Salas, a 26-year-old Air Force Lieutenant at the time of the 1967 malfunction. In a 1996 Great Falls Tribune article, Salas recounted how a security guard reported flying objects performing strange maneuvers and a glowing red object hovering above the front gate. Shortly after, the complex’s ten Minuteman nuclear missiles went offline. Salas emphasized he was not a “UFO junkie” and sought answers to the mystery.

Promotion in Media 🔗

This section outlines the media coverage of the Malmstrom UFO incident. It notes coverage in regional papers starting in 2000, including the Missoula Independent in 2001 and 2002. Air Force documents related to the incident were released under the Freedom of Information Act. Robert Salas authored Faded Giant in 2005, speculating about a government cover-up to exploit extraterrestrial technology. In 2008, UFO author Robert Hastings discussed the incident in his book UFOs and Nukes, which Salas defended. Salas appeared at the National Press Club in 2010 with other UFO speakers and authored Unidentified: The UFO Phenomenon in 2014 and UAPs and the Nuclear Puzzle in 2023. The Great Falls Tribune marked the event’s 50th anniversary in 2017.

Skeptical Views 🔗

This section presents skeptical perspectives on the Malmstrom UFO incident. Science writer Mick West argues that the military investigated the incident and found no connection to UFO sightings, attributing the story’s persistence to Salas’s promotional efforts. Brian Dunning points out discrepancies between Salas’s memories and records from the 341st Strategic Missile Wing, suggesting the missile restart was due to a commonplace power failure and unrelated to later UFO reports. Michael Shermer, appearing with Salas on CNN, suggested that people can be unreliable observers and that extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence. Robert Sheaffer suggests the UFO sighting was likely Mars and unrelated to the missile malfunction.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malmstrom_UFO_incident

item.title: Roswell incident
item.description:
UFO Legend Caused by 1947 Balloon Crash: Roswell Incident 🔗

The Roswell incident is a cornerstone of UFO lore, stemming from the recovery of debris near Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947. Initially reported as a “flying disc” capture, the U.S. Army quickly retracted the statement, claiming it was a weather balloon. This event, coupled with subsequent government explanations and retractions, fueled decades of conspiracy theories alleging a cover-up of extraterrestrial contact.

1947 Military Balloon Crash 🔗

This section details the initial event and its immediate aftermath. In 1947, rancher W.W. “Mac” Brazel discovered debris on his property near Corona, New Mexico. The debris consisted of tinfoil, rubber, tape, and wooden beams. Unaware of the ongoing “flying disc craze,” Brazel initially didn’t connect the debris to UFOs. However, after visiting Corona, his uncle suggested it could be from a “flying disk.” Brazel reported the findings to Sheriff George Wilcox, who contacted Roswell Army Air Field (RAAF).

RAAF sent Major Jesse Marcel and Captain Sheridan Cavitt to investigate. A press release issued by public information officer Walter Haut announced the military’s recovery of a “flying disc.” This announcement made international headlines but was quickly retracted. General Roger Ramey and weather officer Irving Newton identified the material as a weather balloon at a press conference.

UFO Conspiracy Theories (1947–1978) 🔗

This section explores the period between the initial incident and the rise of modern Roswell conspiracy theories. The Roswell debris retrieval faded from public attention for three decades. However, belief in government UFO cover-ups grew, fueled by hoaxes and legends of crashed spaceships and alien bodies in New Mexico. The Aztec, New Mexico crashed saucer hoax introduced the idea of recovered alien bodies, which later became associated with Roswell. The concept of “Hangar 18,” a fictional location at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, emerged as a storage site for alien craft and bodies.

Roswell Conspiracy Theories (1978–1994) 🔗

This section details the resurgence of interest in Roswell and the development of modern conspiracy theories. In 1978, ufologist Stanton Friedman interviewed Jesse Marcel, who stated that the “weather balloon” explanation was a cover story and that he believed the debris was extraterrestrial. This interview, along with subsequent media attention, reignited interest in the Roswell incident.

The 1980 book The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and Bill Moore popularized Marcel’s account and added the claim of alien bodies found on the Plains of San Agustin. The book also connected Marcel’s account to Lydia Sleppy, a former teletype operator who claimed she was ordered to stop transmitting a story about crashed saucer wreckage.

The Majestic 12 hoax, involving faked government documents, emerged in the 1980s, further fueling conspiracy theories. Glenn Dennis, a former mortician, provided an account of extraterrestrial corpses, which was endorsed by prominent Roswell ufologists.

Competing accounts of the Roswell incident led to a schism among ufologists in the early 1990s. UFO Crash at Roswell by Kevin Randle and Donald Schmitt added testimony from new witnesses. Crash at Corona by Stanton Friedman and Don Berliner introduced the idea of two crashed saucers and eight aliens. The Truth About the UFO Crash at Roswell by Randle and Schmitt proposed a new crash site and a different group of archaeologists.

Air Force Response 🔗

This section outlines the official government response to the growing Roswell conspiracy theories. Under pressure from New Mexico congressman Steven Schiff and the General Accounting Office (GAO), the Air Force published reports in the mid-1990s. The initial 1994 report admitted that the weather balloon explanation was a cover story for Project Mogul, a military surveillance program. The 1995 report, The Roswell Report: Fact vs. Fiction in the New Mexico Desert, supported this with documentation that narrowed the cause of the debris to a specific Mogul balloon train. The 1997 report, The Roswell Report: Case Closed, detailed how eyewitness accounts of military personnel loading aliens into “body bags” matched the Air Force’s procedures for retrieving parachute test dummies.

Later Theories and Hoaxes (1994–Present) 🔗

This section covers the continued development of Roswell theories and hoaxes in recent decades. Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction, a pseudo-documentary, played a major role in shaping popular opinion of Roswell. The film centered around Ray Santilli’s hoaxed footage of an alien autopsy.

In 1997, retired army intelligence officer Philip J. Corso released The Day After Roswell, alleging that he was shown a nonhuman body and helped oversee a project to reverse engineer recovered crash debris.

Other theories include Annie Jacobsen’s Area 51: An Uncensored History of America’s Top Secret Military Base, which featured a claim that Nazi doctor Josef Mengele was recruited by Soviet leader Joseph Stalin to produce “grotesque, child-size aviators.”

Explanations 🔗

This section presents the explanations for the Roswell incident, focusing on Project Mogul and anthropomorphic dummies. The Air Force reports identified Project Mogul as the source of the 1947 debris and concluded that other alien crash accounts were likely misidentified military programs or accidents. The 1997 Air Force report concluded that the alleged “bodies” reported by later eyewitnesses came from memories of accidents involving military casualties and memories of the recovery of anthropomorphic dummies.

Cultural Impact 🔗

This section explores the impact of the Roswell incident on tourism, commercialization, and popular fiction. Roswell’s tourism industry is based on ufology museums and businesses, as well as alien-themed iconography. A yearly UFO festival has been held since 1995.

The incident has been depicted in numerous films and television shows, including Hangar 18, Independence Day, The X-Files, and Roswell.

Widespread speculation of a cover-up led to United States presidents being questioned about the Roswell incident.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roswell_UFO_incident

item.title: Roswell incident
item.description:
Roswell Incident 🔗

The Roswell incident refers to the events surrounding the crash of a military balloon near Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947. This event later became the basis for widespread conspiracy theories alleging the recovery of an extraterrestrial spacecraft by the United States military. The article explores the initial event, the subsequent development of UFO conspiracy theories, and the official explanations provided by the United States Air Force.

UFO Legend Caused by 1947 Balloon Crash 🔗

This section introduces the Roswell incident, highlighting the initial newspaper headline that reported the “capture” of a “flying saucer” by the Roswell Army Air Field (RAAF). It sets the stage for the timeline of events, which occurred between June 4 and July 10, 1947, in Lincoln County, New Mexico. The section also mentions the “1947 flying disc craze” and lists related events such as the Kenneth Arnold sighting, the Flight 105 sighting, and various hoaxes.

Military Balloon Debris Recovered in 1947 🔗

This section details the initial event, explaining that military balloon debris was recovered near Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947. It clarifies that this debris later became the basis for conspiracy theories about a crashed extraterrestrial spacecraft. The balloon was part of the top-secret Project Mogul, operated from Alamogordo Army Air Field, designed to detect Soviet nuclear tests. The United States Army initially announced the possession of a “flying disc” but retracted the statement within a day, attributing the debris to a conventional weather balloon to obscure the true purpose.

1947 Military Balloon Crash 🔗

This section provides a detailed account of the events leading up to the Roswell incident. It explains that by 1947, the United States had launched thousands of top-secret Project Mogul balloons to listen for Soviet atomic tests. On June 4, researchers at Alamogordo Army Air Field in New Mexico launched a long train of these balloons, which they lost contact with near Corona, New Mexico, where W.W. “Mac” Brazel’s ranch was located. Brazel discovered tinfoil, rubber, tape, and thin wooden beams scattered across his ranch later that month.

Brazel, initially unaware of the “flying disc craze,” visited Corona on July 5, where his uncle suggested the debris could be from a “flying disk.” The next day, Brazel informed Sheriff George Wilcox of his discovery, who then contacted Roswell Army Air Field (RAAF). Major Jesse Marcel and Captain Sheridan Cavitt were assigned to gather the material. On July 8, RAAF public information officer Walter Haut issued a press release stating that the military had recovered a “flying disc” near Roswell.

The section also describes the press conference where General Roger Ramey, Colonel Thomas DuBose, and weather officer Irving Newton identified the material as pieces of a weather balloon.

UFO Conspiracy Theories (1947–1978) 🔗

This section explains that the 1947 debris retrieval remained relatively obscure for three decades. Reporting ceased after the government provided a mundane explanation, and broader reporting on flying saucers declined rapidly after the Twin Falls saucer hoax. Despite this, belief in UFO cover-ups by the US government became widespread. Hoaxes, legends, and stories of crashed spaceships and alien bodies in New Mexico emerged that later formed elements of the Roswell myth.

Aztec Crashed Saucer Hoax 🔗

This section introduces the Aztec, New Mexico crashed saucer hoax in 1948, which introduced stories of recovered alien bodies that later became associated with Roswell. The hoax narrative included small grey humanoid bodies, metal stronger than any found on Earth, indecipherable writing, and a government coverup to prevent public panic.

Hangar 18 🔗

This section discusses “Hangar 18,” a non-existent location that many later conspiracy theories allege housed extraterrestrial craft or bodies recovered from Roswell. The idea of alien corpses from a crashed ship being stored in an Air Force morgue at the Wright-Patterson Air Force Base was mentioned in Scully’s Behind the Flying Saucers, expanded in the 1966 book Incident at Exeter, and became the basis for a 1968 science-fiction novel The Fortec Conspiracy.

Roswell Conspiracy Theories (1978–1994) 🔗

This section details the rekindling of interest in Roswell after ufologist Stanton Friedman interviewed Jesse Marcel in 1978. Marcel stated that the “weather balloon” explanation from the press conference was a cover story and that he now believed the debris was extraterrestrial. The tabloid National Enquirer brought large-scale attention to the Marcel story the following February.

The Roswell Incident 🔗

This section focuses on the first Roswell conspiracy book, The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and Bill Moore, released in October 1980. The book argues that an extraterrestrial craft was flying over the New Mexico desert to observe nuclear weapons activity when a lightning strike killed the alien crew. It alleges that, after recovering the crashed alien technology, the US government engaged in a cover-up to prevent mass panic.

Majestic 12 Hoax 🔗

This section discusses Majestic 12, the purported organization behind faked government documents delivered anonymously to multiple ufologists in the 1980s. The anonymously delivered documents detailed the creation of a likely fictitious Majestic 12 group formed to handle Roswell debris.

Role of Glenn Dennis 🔗

This section introduces Glenn Dennis, a former mortician who provided an account of extraterrestrial corpses endorsed by prominent Roswell ufologists. Dennis claimed to have received calls from the Air Base with questions about body preservation and inquiries about small or hermetically sealed caskets.

Competing Accounts and Schism 🔗

This section explains that a proliferation of competing Roswell accounts led to a schism among ufologists in the early 1990s. The two leading UFO societies disagreed on the scenarios presented by Randle–Schmitt and Friedman–Berliner.

UFO Crash at Roswell 🔗

This section focuses on Kevin Randle and Donald Schmitt’s book, UFO Crash at Roswell, published in 1991. The book claimed that General Arthur Exon had been aware of debris and bodies, and it included Glenn Dennis’s claims of an alien autopsy and Grady Barnett’s “alien body” accounts.

Crash at Corona 🔗

This section discusses Stanton Friedman’s book, Crash at Corona, co-authored with Don Berliner, released in 1992. The book introduced new “witnesses” and added to the narrative by doubling the number of flying saucers to two, and the number of aliens to eight.

The Truth About the UFO Crash at Roswell 🔗

This section focuses on Randle and Schmitt’s 1994 book, The Truth About the UFO Crash at Roswell, which claimed a cargo plane delivered alien bodies to Dwight D. Eisenhower. The book abandoned the Barnett crash site on the Plains of San Agustin and proposed a new crash site 35 miles north of Roswell.

Air Force Response 🔗

This section details the Air Force’s official responses to Roswell conspiracy theories during the mid-1990s. The initial 1994 USAF report admitted that the weather balloon explanation was a cover story for Project Mogul, a military surveillance program. The following year, The Roswell Report: Fact vs. Fiction in the New Mexico Desert supported this with extensive documentation that narrowed the cause of the debris to a specific Mogul balloon train launched on June 4, 1947, and lost near the Roswell debris field.

Later Theories and Hoaxes (1994–Present) 🔗

This section discusses later theories and hoaxes related to the Roswell incident, including the Alien Autopsy film and Philip J. Corso’s book, The Day After Roswell.

Alien Autopsy 🔗

This section focuses on the pseudo-documentary Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction, which claimed to have footage of an alien autopsy filmed after the 1947 Roswell crash.

The Day After Roswell 🔗

This section discusses Philip J. Corso’s book, The Day After Roswell, released in 1997. Corso alleged that he was shown a purportedly nonhuman body suspended in liquid inside a glass coffin and that he helped oversee a project to reverse engineer recovered crash debris.

Related Debunked or Fringe Theories 🔗

This section mentions related debunked or fringe theories, including Annie Jacobsen’s Area 51: An Uncensored History of America’s Top Secret Military Base, which featured a claim that Nazi doctor Josef Mengele was recruited by Soviet leader Joseph Stalin to produce “grotesque, child-size aviators” to cause hysteria.

Explanations 🔗

This section provides explanations for the Roswell incident, stating that secrecy around the 1947 debris recovery was due to Cold War military programs rather than aliens. It notes that UFO believers maintain that a spacecraft crashed near Roswell, and “Roswell” remains synonymous with UFOs.

Project Mogul 🔗

This section identifies the crashed object from the 1947 incident as a Project Mogul device. Mogul was a military surveillance program employing high-altitude balloons to monitor nuclear tests.

Anthropomorphic Dummies 🔗

This section explains that the 1947 Roswell accounts did not mention alien bodies. The 1997 Air Force report concluded that the alleged “bodies” reported by later eyewitnesses came

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roswell_Incident

item.title: Calvine UFO photograph
item.description:
Calvine UFO photograph 🔗

The Calvine UFO photograph, also known as the Calvine Sighting, refers to a reported UFO sighting near Calvine, Perthshire, Scotland, in August 1990. Two men reported witnessing a diamond-shaped craft while walking on the moors. They took photographs of the object as it hovered silently before ascending vertically and disappearing. The Daily Record newspaper received the story and the original prints and negatives, which were then passed to the Ministry of Defence (MOD). The original materials disappeared, and the story was never published. Investigative journalist David Clarke has led efforts to locate the witnesses. The case gained public interest over the years, with partial documentation released by The National Archives in 2009. An original photograph was discovered by Clarke and published in the Daily Mail in 2022, leading to significant media coverage.

Historical background 🔗

This section provides context for the Calvine sighting within the broader history of UFO photography. It mentions Nick Pope, a former Ministry of Defence desk officer, who included the Calvine sighting in his 1996 book, Open Skies, Closed Minds. Pope described the sighting as intriguing and noted that the MOD’s analysis concluded the photos were likely genuine. The object was described as a solid craft, at least the size of a Harrier or Hawk fighter jet. Sean Kirkpatrick, former director of the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office, has suggested the image is a reflection and may have been doctored.

Release of MOD files 🔗

This section details how the Calvine case gained more public attention after 2008 when the National Archives began releasing MOD UFO reports. David Clarke supervised the release and publication of these files. Among the released documents were materials related to the Calvine sighting, including a government briefing and handwritten summary. Two poor-quality photocopies of images were also included. These files revealed that DI55, a branch of the Directorate of Scientific and Technical Intelligence (DSTI), investigated the images along with a RAF photo analyst agency. Clarke later explored the Calvine incident in his book, The UFO Files.

2015 Channel 5 documentary 🔗

The release of information from the National Archives, along with publicity from Clarke and Pope, led to increasing public interest in the case. In 2015, the incident was featured in the Channel 5 documentary series Conspiracy. The episode, titled “Alien Cover-Up”, included interviews with Clarke and Pope and featured a reconstruction of the sighting. A graphic artist recreated the Calvine photograph for the program, which was later mistaken by some for a genuine image. Pope has speculated on potential links to the alleged Aurora project.

Discovery of the Calvine photograph 🔗

This section describes the renewed investigation led by David Clarke in 2018 to locate the missing photographs and witnesses. Clarke’s interest was sparked by a Defence Intelligence Officer’s claim that the witnesses had photographed a classified U.S. black project platform. Clarke and his team interviewed former MOD staff and conducted public searches. In 2020, Scottish UFOlogist Straiph Wilson launched a search for the hill walkers. Clarke eventually tracked down retired RAF Press Officer Craig Lindsay, who had kept the original photograph for over 32 years. Lindsay donated the print and other items to Sheffield Hallam University’s Special Collection. Andrew Robinson, a photographic specialist, produced high-resolution digital copies and conducted an in-depth analysis, concluding that the photograph is genuine.

The search for Kevin Russell 🔗

This section focuses on the search for a person named Kevin Russell, whose name was written on the back of the original Calvine photograph. The name was believed to be that of one of the witnesses. Despite contacting over 400 people with that name, Clarke’s team was unable to identify the witness. A person named Kevin Russell who worked at a hotel in Pitlochry was identified, but he denied any knowledge of the UFO. Nick Pope acknowledges being aware of the name Kevin Russell but declined to comment.

The Program documentary (2024) 🔗

This section discusses the documentary The Program by James Fox, released in December 2024, which features the Calvine UFO case. Fox interviewed David Clarke and Robinson in Sheffield and Lindsay in Scotland. The film explores the U.S. congressional effort to uncover government knowledge about UFOs and UAPs and includes an in-depth review of the Calvine case.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Calvine_UFO

item.title: Unidentified flying object
item.description:
Unidentified Flying Object (UFO) 🔗

An unidentified flying object (UFO), also known as unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP) or unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP), is defined as an object or phenomenon observed in the sky that cannot be readily identified or explained. While reports of unusual aerial sightings date back centuries, the term “UFO” gained prominence after World War II, particularly during the Space Age. Investigations into UFO reports have been conducted by governments, organizations, and individuals, but no definitive confirmation of claims suggesting extraterrestrial origins or other unconventional explanations has emerged. Skeptics often attribute UFO sightings to misidentified natural phenomena, human technology, delusions, or hoaxes.

Terminology 🔗

The terms “flying saucers” or “flying discs” were initially used to describe UFOs, stemming from the Kenneth Arnold incident. Captain Edward J. Ruppelt of the USAF coined the acronym “UFO” to encompass a broader range of reported shapes and performances. “Unidentified aerial phenomena” (UAP) emerged later, gaining traction in the 21st century due to negative connotations associated with “UFO.” The term “extra-terrestrial vehicle” (ETV) is sometimes used to distinguish between extraterrestrial and earthbound explanations for UFOs.

Identification 🔗

Most UFOs, upon investigation, are identified as ordinary objects or phenomena. Common sources of UFO reports include aircraft, astronomical objects, balloons, hoaxes, light phenomena, other atmospheric objects and phenomena, and psychological effects. Studies have shown that misidentification of prosaic phenomena, often due to inexperience or misperception, is a primary factor in UFO sightings. Astronomer Andrew Fraknoi encourages critical thinking when evaluating UFO claims, suggesting that thorough investigation often reveals less mystery than initially perceived.

History 🔗

Early history before the 20th century 🔗

Throughout history, people have observed unusual sights in the sky, including comets, meteors, planets, and atmospheric optical phenomena. These events were often interpreted as supernatural portents or religious omens. While some UFO enthusiasts draw parallels between religious symbols in medieval paintings and UFO reports, art historians typically offer conventional religious interpretations.

Examples of pre-contemporary reports include:

  • Julius Obsequens’ Liber de prodigiis, which describes objects moving through the sky in ancient Rome.
  • Shen Kuo’s Dream Pool Essays, which recounts eyewitness testimony of a flying object with opening doors and blinding light in 11th-century China.
  • Woodcuts from the 16th century depicting celestial phenomena over Nuremberg and Basel, which some connect to ancient astronaut claims.
  • A report in the Denison Daily News in 1878, where a farmer described seeing a large, dark, circular object resembling a saucer.

20th century and after 🔗

During World War II, Allied and Axis pilots reported seeing round, glowing fireballs known as “foo fighters.” In 1946, the Swedish military collected over 2,000 reports of unidentified aerial objects, referred to as “ghost rockets.”

The modern UFO phenomenon gained momentum with the media frenzy surrounding Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting near Mount Rainier. Arnold described seeing “flying saucers,” sparking widespread public interest. Weeks later, the Roswell incident occurred, involving the recovery of debris from a downed observation balloon.

In the 1950s, “saucer clubs” emerged, and books like Donald Keyhoe’s The Flying Saucers Are Real popularized the extraterrestrial hypothesis. Media speculation intensified, particularly during the 1952 UFO scare in Washington, D.C.

From 1947, the U.S. Air Force investigated UFO reports through Project Sign, Project Grudge, and Project Blue Book. Project Blue Book cataloged 12,618 sightings. The Condon Report in 1968 concluded that further UFO studies were not justified.

From the 1960s to 1990s, UFOs became integrated into popular culture, with alien abduction accounts like the Barney and Betty Hill incident gaining prominence. Films like Close Encounters of the Third Kind and Alien, along with TV series like In Search of… and The X-Files, fueled public fascination.

In December 2017, media attention resurfaced with the revelation of the secret Advanced Aviation Threat Identification Program. Leaked Pentagon UFO videos led to increased mainstream interest. In July 2021, Harvard astronomer Avi Loeb announced the Galileo Project, aiming to seek evidence of extraterrestrial artifacts. Government programs like NASA’s UAP independent study team and the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office were established to investigate UFO claims. Congressional hearings were held in 2022 and 2023, featuring whistleblower claims from former U.S. Air Force officer David Grusch.

Public belief in UFOs varies, with polls indicating that a significant percentage of Americans believe UFOs are evidence of alien life.

Notable cases and incidents 🔗

Notable cases and incidents include:

  • Britain: The Rendlesham Forest incident (1980).
  • France: The Valensole UFO incident (1965) and the Trans-en-Provence Case (1981).
  • United States: The Kecksburg UFO incident (1965), the Travis Walton abduction claim (1975), and the Phoenix Lights (1997).

Famous hoaxes include the Maury Island incident and the Gulf Breeze UFO incident.

Investigations of reports 🔗

UFO reports have been investigated by governments and academics in various countries. No official government investigation has definitively confirmed that UFOs are real, physical objects of extraterrestrial origin.

Well-known government studies include:

  • The ghost rockets investigation by the Swedish military (1946–1947).
  • Project Blue Book, Project Sign, and Project Grudge by the USAF (1947–1969).
  • Project Twinkle investigation into green fireballs (1948–1951).
  • Project Blue Book Special Report No. 14 by the Battelle Memorial Institute.
  • Brazilian Air Force’s Operação Prato (1977).
  • France’s GEPAN/SEPRA/GEIPAN (1977–present).
  • Uruguay’s government investigation (1989–present).

Americas 🔗

  • Brazil (1952–2016): The National Archives of Brazil has been receiving documentation from the Brazilian Air Force regarding UFO investigations.
  • Chile (c. 1968): The SEFAA (previously CEFAA) receives case reports from the public, civil aviators, and the Chilean Air Force.
  • Canada (c. 1950): The Department of National Defence has investigated UFO reports, including the Falcon Lake incident and the Shag Harbour UFO incident. Early studies included Project Magnet and Project Second Storey.
  • United States: U.S. investigations include Project Sign, Project Grudge, Project Blue Book, Project Twinkle, the CIA’s Directorate of Science & Technology study, the Robertson Panel, the Brookings Report, the Condon Committee, the RAND Corporation study, the Mutual UFO Network (MUFON), the National Investigations Committee On Aerial Phenomena (NICAP), the Center for UFO Studies (CUFOS), the Sturrock panel, the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program, and the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office.

USAAF and FBI response to the 1947 sightings 🔗

Following a surge in sightings in 1947, the USAAF and FBI began a formal investigation. A preliminary defense estimate concluded that “something is really flying around.”

USAF 🔗

Projects Sign (1947–1949), Grudge (1948–1951), and Blue Book (1951–1970) 🔗

Project Sign’s final report stated that there was not enough data to determine the origin of some UFOs. In August 1948, Sign investigators wrote a top-secret intelligence estimate concluding an extraterrestrial origin, but the Air Force Chief of Staff ordered it destroyed.

Another classified U.S. study by the CIA in 1952 concluded that UFOs were real physical objects of potential threat to national security.

Project Sign was dismantled and became Project Grudge, which was later reorganized as Project Blue Book. J. Allen Hynek, a scientific advisor for Project Blue Book, became critical of the program’s scientific rigor.

USAF Regulation 200-2 (1953–1954) 🔗

Air Force Regulation 200-2 defined an Unidentified Flying Object (“UFOB”) and outlined procedures for investigation and reporting.

Blue Book and the Condon Committee (1968–1970) 🔗

The Condon Report in 1968 arrived at a negative conclusion regarding UFOs. Project Blue Book closed down in 1970. However, a 1969 USAF document, known as the Bolender memo, revealed that non-public U.S. government UFO investigations continued after 1970.

FOIA release of documents in 1978 🔗

Documents released under the Freedom of Information Act in 1978 indicated serious behind-the-scenes

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO

item.title: UFO (disambiguation)
item.description:
UFO (disambiguation) 🔗

This page serves as a disambiguation for the term “UFO,” which primarily refers to an unidentified flying object, an aerial phenomenon that cannot be immediately identified or explained. However, “UFO” is also used in various other contexts.

Computer Technology 🔗

This section lists various uses of “UFO” in the realm of computer technology. It includes:

  • .ufo: The file extension for Ulead PhotoImpact documents.
  • Unified File and Object (UFO): An object storage architecture.
  • UHF Follow-On satellite: A series of US military communications satellites.
  • Unified Font Object: An XML-based open format for digital fonts.
  • Unified Foundational Ontology: An upper ontology for conceptual modeling.

Art, Entertainment and Media 🔗

This section covers the diverse applications of “UFO” in art, entertainment, and media, broken down into film and television, music, and video games.

Film and Television 🔗

This subsection lists several films and television series with “UFO” in their titles:

  • UFO (1956 film): Directed by Winston Jones.
  • U.F.O. (1993 film): Starring Roy “Chubby” Brown.
  • U.F.O. (2012 film): Featuring Jean-Claude Van Damme.

Bands and Performers 🔗

  • UFO: The original name of the English R&B group better known as JLS.

  • “UFO”: A song by D-Block Europe and Aitch from the album The Blue Print: Us vs. Them (2020).

Other Musical Works 🔗

  • UFO (Michael Daugherty composition): A musical composition.
  • UFOetry: A multimedia UFO rock opera.

Video Games 🔗

UFO Defense Family 🔗

  • UFO: Aftermath (2003)
  • UFO: Aftershock (2005)

Other Video Games 🔗

Other Works 🔗

  • UFOs: The Greatest Stories: A 1996 short-story anthology by Martin H. Greenberg.

Games and Sports 🔗

  • Claw vending machine: Also known as UFO.
  • UFO: A style of delivery in Ten-pin bowling.

Clubs 🔗

This section lists clubs with “UFO” in their names:

  • Ufo (Club, Berlin): An Acid House club.
  • UFO Club: A London underground club.

Products and Services 🔗

This section lists products and services branded with “UFO”:

  • UFO: A brand of instant yakisoba.
  • UFO (restaurant): A restaurant in Slovakia.
  • UFO (ride): An amusement park ride.

Other Uses 🔗

This section lists other miscellaneous uses of the acronym “UFO”:

  • United Farmers of Ontario: A Canadian political party c. 1920s.

See Also 🔗

item.title: List of alien races in DC Comics
item.description:
List of Alien Races in DC Comics 🔗

This is a comprehensive list of extraterrestrial races that have appeared in DC Comics, including comic books and other media. It provides brief descriptions and citations for each race.

Overview 🔗

The DC Comics universe contains a vast number of alien races, most of which are humanoid.

United Planets 🔗

The United Planets is a governing body active from the 21st to the 31st centuries. Members include planets of the Solar System, Htrae, artificial planet-sized satellites, buffer planets seeded by Mon-El, and neighboring empires. In the 21st century, the United Planets are led by the corrupt Durlan Thaaros.

0-9 🔗

5th Dimensional Imps 🔗

Zrfff is the homeworld of 5th Dimensional Imps, including Mister Mxyzptlk, Miss Gsptlsnz, Vyndktvx, Brpxz, Mister Genie (Genro), Quisp, Bat-Mite, Kcid Nosyarg (Larry), Zook, Gazook, and Mopee. In other media, 5th Dimensional Imps appear in Supergirl, consisting of Mxyzptlk and Gsptlsnz / Nyxlygsptlnz. The Music Meister is revealed to be an imp in a Supergirl crossover with The Flash.

A 🔗

Adaptoids 🔗

The Adaptoids are blob-like creatures from the vicinity of Arcturus that attempted to wipe out the human race on Earth-One. They were defeated by the Justice League when exposed to the Thanagarian equalizing disease.

Aellans 🔗

The Aellans are yellow-skinned reptilian humanoids from Aello (Stormswift), Demonia, Harpis, and Doc of Aello were all members of the Omega Men.

Alien Invaders 🔗

The Alien Invaders are the nameless primary antagonists of Armageddon: The Alien Agenda.

Almeraci 🔗

The Almeraci are a humanoid race of technologically advanced warriors with psionic abilities, ruled by the House of the Blood Royale, a matriarchy of superpowered monarchs. They choose mates through ceremonial gladiatorial competitions. Maxima, Queen of Almerac, her handmaiden Sazu, and her onetime betrothed Ultraa represent this species.

Aloi 🔗

The Aloi are blue-skinned aliens with ridged foreheads at war with the Margoi over a device known as the “Grayl”. Tumlat represents them.

Alstairans 🔗

The Alstairans of Alstair are plantlike humanoids with leaves instead of hair, one of four technologically advanced spacefaring races native to the Antares system. Their ruler is the alien plant elemental Hyathis.

Anasazi 🔗

The Anasazi are metahumans resettled to planet Starhaven, represented by Dawnstar.

Andromedans 🔗

The Andromedans of the Andromeda Galaxy are a race of superhumans similar to Kryptonians and Daxamites, with red hair, albino skin, and blue eyes. Karb-Brak was exiled to Earth and later cured by Superman and Vartox.

Angtuans 🔗

The Angtuans are inhabitants of the planet Angtu, a world with a thick, noxious atmosphere. Angtu was destroyed in the 30th century by the mutated native Mano.

Anunnake 🔗

The Anunnake are reptilian aliens who claim to have killed off the dinosaurs; they are also known as the Hunter/Gatherers.

Anndrann 🔗

The Anndrann are green-skinned military geniuses from Anndranna, later banished to Bellatrix, famed for their weapons of war. Iron has a deleterious effect on their cognitive abilities.

Appellaxians 🔗

The Appellaxians of Appellax are technologically advanced energy aliens with the ability to create powerful artificial host bodies for their minds. The seven Appellaxians that invaded created bodies named Golden Roc, Wood King, Stone-God, Crystal Creature, Fire-Lord, Glass-Man, and Mercury Monster. The Justice League first came together because of them. In Young Justice, Bruno Mannheim combines them into a Golem using a Mother Box, before it is destroyed by Black Beetle.

Aipitons 🔗

The Aipitons are the presumed name of a species of small flying insects of the planet Apaiton, represented by the deceased Green Lantern Bzzd.

Aquoids 🔗

The Aquoids are natives of planet Beltair IV.

Aranes 🔗

The Aranes of Arane II are light blue-skinned, white-haired humanoids with tiny blue protruding horns on their foreheads. Rolind Siepur of Arane II is a member of the Dark Circle.

Ardenans 🔗

The Ardenans are the presumed name of a sentient race of humanoids with orange scaly skin from the planet Arden, represented by the deceased Green Lanterns Lodar and Meeno Monak.

Astonians 🔗

The Astonians are a minor alien race under a once dying star saved by the Blue Lantern Saint Walker upon facing extinction. Saint Walker is of this race.

Azarathians 🔗

The Azarathians are people belonging to the parallel universe of Azarath. Raven is an Azarathian.

B 🔗

Barrions 🔗

The Barrions of Barrio III are silicon-based lifeforms, represented by the Green Lantern Chaselon.

Bellatrix Bombers 🔗

The Bellatrix Bombers are alien warlords featured in Green Lantern (vol. 3) #20.

Bgztlians 🔗

The Bgztlians are humans from the colony Bgztl who possess the metahuman ability of intangibility. Phantom Girl of the Legion of Super-Heroes is their representative.

Blight 🔗

The Blight are a cybernetic race whose bodies are composed of rotting flesh and villains of the Legion of Super-Heroes. Their leader is Atrophos.

Bloodline Parasites 🔗

The eight Bloodline Parasites were extraterrestrial lifeforms capable of accidentally activating the human metagene during the act of feeding on human spinal fluid.

Braalians 🔗

The Braalians are humans from the colony Braal who possess the metahuman ability of electromagnetic field manipulation. Cosmic Boy and Magno of the Legion of Super-Heroes are their representatives.

Brain-Parasites of Planet X 🔗

The Brain-Parasites of Planet X hail from Planet X and use powerful Knowledge-Extractors to steal knowledge from other races.

Branx 🔗

The Branx of Emana Branx are a gray-skinned race of dull-witted, four-armed warriors who serve the Citadelians.

Brylyx 🔗

The Brylyx are white-skinned aliens featured in Green Lantern: Mosaic.

The Bolovax Vikians 🔗

The Bolovax Vikians are highly communal and technologically advanced. Bolovax Vikians of Bolovax Vik are a dead race. Kilowog of the Green Lantern Corps is the last surviving member of this species. A holographic Bolovax Vikian appears in the My Adventures with Superman episode “The Machine Who Would Be Empire”.

Bugs of New Genesis 🔗

The Bugs of New Genesis are an insectoid race who were spread on New Genesis during their war with Apokolips. Forager and Mantis are the most prominent members of the race.

C 🔗

Cairnians 🔗

The Cairnians are members of L.E.G.I.O.N.

Calatonians 🔗

The Calatonians are an ancient monarchy on the planet Calaton ravaged by the Doomsday creature.

Canopians 🔗

The Canopians are a member of Atari Force. Canopians such as Morphea are from New Earth in a parallel universe.

Carggites 🔗

The Carggites are humans from the colony Cargg who possess the metahuman ability of duplication. Triplicate Girl of the Legion of Super-Heroes is their representative.

Catherix 🔗

The Cathexis are a race of alien super-scientists from the “sixth dimension” who created self-aware reality endangering technology.

Changralynians 🔗

The Changralynians of Changralyn are a race of silicon-based pacifists, they are represented by Broot of the Omega Men.

Children of Tanjent 🔗

The Children of Tanjent are a psionic race.

Circadians 🔗

The peaceful insectoid Circadians of Circadia established a joint human/Circadian settlement in the 30th Century known as Pax Colony. Circadia Senius is a Chronarch Research Fellow at the Metropolis Time Institute and a friend of Brainiac 5.

Citadelians 🔗

The Citadelians of the Citadel are a race of sadistic imperialistic clones, whose intellect and genetic viability degrades with each newly cloned generation.

Clementians 🔗

The Clementians of Clementia are also known as “Black Mercies”. The Green Lantern Mother Mercy is the caretaker and ruler of the Clementian race.

Coluans 🔗

The Coluans (sometimes known as Yod-Colu) of Colu are a hyper-intelligent species, one of the most technologically advanced in the known universe. They are most notably represented by the various men and women who hold the title of Brainiac along with Pulsar Stargrave. The planet Colu was destroyed by the Omega Titans in Justice League: No Justice. The Coluans appear in *

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thanagarian

List of Alien Races in DC Comics 🔗

This Wikipedia article provides a comprehensive list of fictional extraterrestrial races that have appeared in DC Comics publications and related media. It includes brief descriptions and citations for each race.

Contents 🔗

This section lists the alphabetical index of alien races covered in the article, from 0-9 to Z, along with links to “See also,” “References,” and “External links” sections.

Overview 🔗

This section introduces the concept of the vast number of extraterrestrial races in the DC Comics universe, noting that the majority are humanoid in structure.

United Planets 🔗

This section discusses the United Planets, a governing body active from the 21st to the 31st centuries. It mentions known members like planets of the Solar System, Htrae, buffer planets seeded by Mon-El, and neighboring empires. It also notes that in the 21st century, the United Planets are led by the corrupt Durlan Thaaros. The section is marked as needing expansion.

0-9 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with numbers.

5th Dimensional Imps 🔗

This section details the 5th Dimensional Imps from the planet Zrfff, including notable characters like Mister Mxyzptlk, Miss Gsptlsnz, Vyndktvx, Bat-Mite, and Zook. It also mentions their appearances in other media, such as the Supergirl TV series, where Mxyzptlk and Nyxlygsptlnz appear, and a Supergirl crossover with The Flash, where the Music Meister is revealed to be an imp.

A 🔗

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “A.”

Adaptoids 🔗

This section describes the Adaptoids, blob-like creatures from the vicinity of Arcturus who attempted to wipe out the human race on Earth-One. They were defeated by the Justice League when exposed to the Thanagarian equalizing disease.

Aellans 🔗

This section details the Aellans, yellow-skinned reptilian humanoids from Aello, Demonia, and Harpis. Harpis and Doc of Aello were members of the Omega Men.

Alien Invaders 🔗

This section identifies the Alien Invaders as the nameless primary antagonists of Armageddon: The Alien Agenda.

Almeraci 🔗

This section describes the Almeraci, a humanoid race of technologically advanced warriors with psionic abilities, ruled by the matriarchal House of the Blood Royale. Key figures include Maxima, Queen of Almerac, her handmaiden Sazu, and Ultraa.

Aloi 🔗

This section details the Aloi, blue-skinned aliens with ridged foreheads at war with the Margoi over a device called the “Grayl.” Tumlat represents them.

Alstairans 🔗

This section describes the Alstairans of Alstair, plantlike humanoids with leaves instead of hair, constantly at war with other races in the Antares system. Their ruler is Hyathis, an alien plant elemental.

Anasazi 🔗

This section identifies the Anasazi as metahumans resettled to the planet Starhaven, represented by Dawnstar.

Angtuans 🔗

Anndrann 🔗

This section details the Anndrann, green-skinned military geniuses from Anndranna, famed for their weapons of war. Iron has a negative effect on their cognitive abilities.

This section describes the Appellaxians of Appellax, technologically advanced energy aliens with the ability to create powerful artificial host bodies. The seven Appellaxians that invaded created bodies named Golden Roc, Wood King, Stone-God, Crystal Creature, Fire-Lord, Glass-Man, and Mercury Monster. Their invasion led to the formation of the Justice League. The section also mentions their appearance in Young Justice, where Bruno Mannheim combines them into a Golem.

This section describes the Bloodline Parasites, extraterrestrial lifeforms capable of activating the human metagene while feeding on spinal fluid. They have exoskeletons, strength, and the ability to duplicate human form.

This section describes the Carggites, humans from the colony Cargg who possess the metahuman ability of duplication. Triplicate Girl of the Legion of Super-Heroes represents them.

This section details the Cathexis, alien super-scientists from the “sixth dimension” who created self-aware reality-endangering technology.
