item.title: Alien Nation
item.description:
Alien Nation 🔗

A science fiction police procedural television series that aired on Fox from 1989 to 1990. It’s based on the 1988 film Alien Nation.

Plot 🔗

The series is set in the near future, beginning in 1990, after a flying saucer crashes in the Mojave Desert. The ship contains the Tenctonese, a race of extraterrestrials escaping slavery. They are accepted as immigrants to the US, and the series explores their integration into American society. Storylines often address themes of racism and bigotry, using the Newcomers as a stand-in for discriminated minorities. The series uses social commentary to illustrate what it means to be human and the often bizarre rituals we observe.

Cast 🔗

  • Detective Matthew “Matt” Sikes: Played by Gary Graham, a human detective partnered with George Francisco.
  • Detective George Francisco: Played by Eric Pierpoint, a Newcomer detective partnered with Matthew Sikes.
  • Susan Francisco: Played by Michele Scarabelli, George’s wife, a Newcomer advertising businesswoman.
  • Emily Francisco: Played by Lauren Woodland, George and Susan’s young daughter.
  • Buck Francisco: Played by Sean Six, George and Susan’s initially delinquent teenage son.
  • Cathy Frankel: Played by Terri Treas, Matt’s Newcomer neighbor and on-off girlfriend, a bio-chemist.
  • Albert Einstein: Played by Jeff Marcus, a timid Newcomer janitor working at the police department.
  • Cpt. Bryon Grazer: Played by Ron Fassler, Matt and George’s human superior officer.
  • Beatrice Zepeda: Played by Jenny Gago, a human detective in Matt and George’s squad.
  • Burns: Played by Jeff Doucette, a human photographer.
  • Sergeant Dobbs: Played by Lawrence Hilton-Jacobs, a human police officer.
  • Jill: Played by Molly Morgan, a human girl and Emily’s friend.
  • Uncle Moodri: Played by James Greene, an eccentric but wise Newcomer and member of the Francisco family.

Production 🔗

Kenneth Johnson, responsible for other science-fiction television series, was approached for the television adaptation of the 1988 film Alien Nation. He initially had no interest in the project but was later inspired to create a series focusing on social commentary about the integration of a new minority group.

Changes from the film 🔗

Several changes were made from the original film. The human detective Matthew Sykes was played by James Caan in the film, but Gary Graham in the TV series. Detective George Francisco was played by Mandy Patinkin in the film, but Eric Pierpoint in the TV series. The TV series explores Newcomer culture more deeply than the film. Francisco’s family also differs, with a daughter, Emily, added to the TV series.

Cancellation 🔗

The series ran for one season on Fox. Despite building a strong fan base, the show was cancelled due to the network’s financial difficulties. The season ended on a cliffhanger, and popular demand led to the unproduced second season premiere being adapted as a novel and comic book. Years later, Fox produced five television films to continue the story.

Episodes 🔗

The series consists of 22 episodes, each dealing with the integration of the Newcomers into human society and the challenges they face. The episodes often involve police procedural elements, with Sikes and Francisco investigating crimes involving both humans and Newcomers.

Television films 🔗

Five television films continued the story after the series’ cancellation:

  • Alien Nation: Dark Horizon (1994)
  • Alien Nation: Body and Soul (1995)
  • Alien Nation: Millennium (1996)
  • Alien Nation: The Enemy Within (1996)
  • Alien Nation: The Udara Legacy (1997)

Home media 🔗

The complete series was released on DVD by 20th Century Fox in 2006. The five television films were later released as a collection.

Revival 🔗

In 2009, Syfy announced a new take on the series with Tim Minear writing. However, the series was later cancelled. In 2015, a remake was reported to be in the works with Art Marcum and Matt Holloway writing the script.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Nation_(TV_series)

item.title: UFO sightings in Argentina
item.description:
List of alleged UFO sightings in the nation of Argentina 🔗

This article presents a compilation of reported UFO sightings in Argentina, spanning from 1962 to 2023.

May 1962 🔗

This section details several UFO sightings that occurred in May 1962, primarily around Bahía Blanca. Key events include:

  • Sightings at the Espora Air Base on May 11 and 18.
  • An encounter on Route 35 where three truck drivers witnessed an illuminated object rising from a field and dividing into two parts.
  • A photograph taken by Miguel Tohmé in Bahía Blanca on May 21, depicting a UFO “the size of a soccer ball.”
  • Sightings at the Port Belgrano Naval Base between May 21 and 23.

16 July 1965 🔗

This section describes a sighting in Buenos Aires on July 16, 1965, where two bright disks were observed remaining stationary before flying away at high speed. The Seventh Air Brigade dispatched three Gloster Meteor aircraft from Morón Air Base to investigate, but the search yielded no results.

1 December 1965 🔗

This section refers to the Adhara Observatory UFO Lunar Transit. On December 1, 1965, at 8:30 pm, the Adhara Observatory in San Miguel, Buenos Aires province, received calls about strange objects visible on the moon. Photographs taken by the observatory staff revealed disk-shaped objects flying in front of the moon. Some experts suggest these objects may have been caused by film processing errors.

27 October 1973 🔗

This section recounts the experience of truck driver Dionisio Llanca, who was admitted to the Municipal Hospital of Bahía Blanca on October 30. Llanca claimed that on October 27, he encountered an intense light while changing a tire on his way to Río Gallegos, which paralyzed him. He reported seeing an object in the sky and beings who subjected him to medical testing. He awoke hours later approximately 9 kilometers away. UFO researcher Fabio Zerpa investigated the case and published it in his book El Reino Subterráneo.

9 January 1986 🔗

This section discusses an alleged UFO landing on Mount Pajarillo, near Capilla del Monte. An 11-year-old local child, Gabriel Gomez, witnessed the event. The following day, a circular footprint, known as “Huella del Pajarillo,” appeared near Cerro Uritorco, believed to be the result of a UFO landing that burned the area in a circular shape.

25 December 1988 🔗

This section describes a sighting over Villa Urquiza, Buenos Aires, where a silver UFO flew over the high-density area. This event is considered one of Argentina’s most spectacular UFO incidents, with over 7,500 witnesses. The local airport reported an object flying west towards General Paz Avenue, detected on radar on that sunny afternoon.

5 September 2023 🔗

This section details an incident at the Espora Air Base near Bahía Blanca. On that night, four black, triangular UFOs allegedly flew over the base and were engaged with gunfire by military personnel. One object reportedly fired a laser, injuring two or three soldiers. The Base denied the incident, claiming that videos and audios circulating were edited fake news.

See also 🔗

This section provides a link to the “List of reported UFO sightings” page.

Notes 🔗

This section contains footnotes referencing the sources used for each of the sightings described in the article.

External links 🔗

This section provides an external link to MUFON (Mutual UFO Network) for recent UFO sightings and pictures.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_Argentina

item.title: Close encounter
item.description:
Close Encounter 🔗

A close encounter, in ufology, is defined as an event where a person witnesses an unidentified flying object (UFO) at close range, reducing the likelihood of misidentification. The term and classification system were introduced by astronomer and UFO researcher J. Allen Hynek in his 1972 book, The UFO Experience: A Scientific Inquiry. While others have expanded on Hynek’s original categories, these extensions haven’t gained widespread acceptance due to a perceived lack of scientific rigor. Sightings beyond 150 meters are generally classified as daylight discs, nocturnal lights, or radar/visual reports.

Hynek’s Scale 🔗

J. Allen Hynek created a six-level classification system for UFO sightings, arranged by proximity. The categories include:

  1. Nocturnal Lights: Unexplained lights observed in the night sky.
  2. Daylight Discs: UFOs seen during the day, typically disc-shaped or oval.
  3. Radar-Visual: UFO sightings confirmed by radar, intended to provide more concrete evidence, though atmospheric anomalies can sometimes explain radar propagation.
  4. Close Encounters of the First Kind (CE1): Visual sightings of a UFO at close range (less than 150 meters), displaying appreciable angular extension and detail.
  5. Close Encounters of the Second Kind (CE2): UFO events involving physical effects, such as interference with vehicles or electronics, animal reactions, physiological effects on witnesses, or physical traces like ground impressions or scorched vegetation.
  6. Close Encounters of the Third Kind (CE3): UFO encounters where animated entities are present, including humanoids, robots, or humans seemingly associated with the UFO.

Bloecher Subtypes 🔗

Ted Bloecher proposed six subtypes for Close Encounters of the Third Kind:

  1. Aboard: An entity is observed only inside the UFO.
  2. Both: An entity is observed both inside and outside the UFO.
  3. Close: An entity is observed near a UFO, but not entering or exiting it.
  4. Direct: An entity is observed without any UFOs being seen, but UFO activity has been reported in the area around the same time.
  5. Excluded: An entity is observed, but no UFOs are seen, and no UFO activity has been reported in the area at that time.
  6. Frequence: No entity or UFOs are observed, but the subject experiences some form of “intelligent communication.”

Extensions of Hynek’s Scale 🔗

Following Hynek’s death in 1986, Jacques Vallee expanded the classification system by adding Close Encounters of the Fourth and Fifth Kinds, detailed in his 1990 book, Confrontations: A Scientist’s Search for Alien Contact. These extensions were quickly adopted by the Mutual UFO Network (MUFON).

Close Encounters of the Fourth Kind (CE4) 🔗

A CE4 involves a human being abducted by a UFO or its occupants. Jacques Vallée suggested that the “fourth kind” should encompass cases where witnesses experience a transformation of their sense of reality, including non-abduction events with absurd, hallucinatory, or dreamlike elements associated with UFO encounters.

Close Encounters of the Fifth Kind (CE5) 🔗

In Vallee’s original definition, a CE5 occurs when an alien abductee experiences a physical effect from the encounter, such as injury or healing.

An alternate interpretation, popularized by Steven M. Greer, defines CE5 as human-initiated contact with extraterrestrial life forms or advanced interstellar civilizations, involving direct communication between aliens and humans. This involves individuals or groups using specific protocols, primarily contact meditation and sounds or signals, to establish communication or interaction with extraterrestrial beings. This is also referred to as human-initiated close encounter.

Close Encounters of the Sixth Kind (CE6) 🔗

This term describes a sexual encounter between a human and an extraterrestrial species.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Close_encounter

item.title: Flying saucer
item.description:
Flying Saucer 🔗

A flying saucer, or flying disc, is a purported type of disc-shaped unidentified flying object (UFO). The term originated in 1947 when US news media reported pilot Kenneth Arnold’s claim of seeing objects flying near his airplane over Washington State. The news reports included implausible speed estimates and preceded a wave of sightings across the US, including the Roswell incident and the Flight 105 UFO sighting. A National Guard pilot died in 1948 while pursuing a flying saucer. Civilian research groups and conspiracy theories developed around the topic, and the concept spread to other countries. Early reports speculated about secret military technology, but flying saucers became associated with aliens by 1950. The terms unidentified flying object (UFO) and unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP) have gradually replaced the term over time.

An aerial photo taken over Lake Cote, Costa Rica, by Sergio Loaiza in 1971 is included.

In science fiction, UFO sightings, UFO conspiracy theories, and popular culture, saucers are typically piloted by nonhuman beings. Most reported sightings describe saucers in the distance and do not mention a crew. Descriptions of the craft vary considerably. Early reports emphasized speed, but the descriptions shifted over the decades to the objects mostly hovering. They are generally said to be round, sometimes with a protrusion on top, but details of the shape vary between reports. Witnesses describe flying saucers as silent or deafening, with lights of every color, and flying alone or in formation. Size estimates range from small enough to fit in a living room to over 2,000 feet (610 m) in diameter. Sightings are most frequent at night. Astronomer Donald Howard Menzel concluded that the reports were too varied to all be describing the same type of objects. Experts have identified most reported saucers as known phenomena, including astronomical objects such as Venus, airborne objects such as balloons, and optical phenomena such as sun dogs.

1950s pop culture embraced flying saucers. The discs appeared in film, television, literature, music, toys, and advertising. Their reports influenced religious movements and were the subject of military investigations. The shape became visual shorthand for alien invaders. During the 1960s, saucers waned in popularity as UFOs were reported and depicted in other shapes. Discs ceased to be viewed as the standard shape for alien spacecraft but are still often depicted, sometimes for their retro value to evoke the early Cold War era.

History 🔗

Reports of fantastical aircraft predate the first flying saucers. In antiquity, mysterious lights in the sky were interpreted as spiritual phenomena. In the 1800s, many newspapers reported massive airships with glowing lights and humming engines. These are often seen as precursors to flying saucer and UFO sightings. On January 25, 1878, the Denison Daily News printed an article in which John Martin, a local farmer, reported an object resembling a balloon flying “at wonderful speed”. The newspaper said it appeared to be about the size of a saucer from his perspective, one of the first uses of the word “saucer” in association with a UFO. An outbreak of a number of sightings of mystery airships occurred in America in 1896 and 1897. During World War II, Allied pilots reported balls of light following their planes. They named the lights foo fighters and believed they were advanced Axis aircraft.

Many aspects of the typical flying saucer first appeared in science fiction. French sociologist Bertrand Méheust noted Jean de La Hire’s 1908 novel La Roue fulgurante (The Lightning Wheel). In the novel, a flying disc-shaped machine abducts the protagonists via a beam of light. Science fiction magazine Amazing Stories began publishing “The Shaver Mystery” in 1945. Written by Richard Sharpe Shaver and edited by Raymond A. Palmer, they were science fiction tales about technologically advanced “detrimental robots” that abducted humans, but the stories were presented as a true account of Shaver’s life. Until the magazine ceased printing The Shaver Mystery, Amazing Stories’ letter column was regularly full of readers sharing their own purportedly true sightings of the robots.

Before the flying saucer was coined as a term, fantasy artwork in pulp magazines depicted flying discs. Skeptical physicist Milton Rothman noted the appearance of so-called flying saucers in the fantasy artwork of 1930s pulp science fiction magazines, by artists such as Frank R. Paul. One of Paul’s earliest depictions of a flying saucer appeared on the cover of the November 1929 issue of Hugo Gernsback’s pulp science fiction magazine Science Wonder Stories. Science fiction illustrator Frank Wu wrote that the idea of space vehicles shaped like flying saucers was imprinted in the national psyche for many years prior to 1947, when the Roswell incident took place.

Origins 🔗

The modern flying saucer concept, including the association with aliens, can be traced to the 1947 Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting. On June 24, 1947, businessman and amateur pilot Kenneth Arnold landed at the Yakima, Washington airstrip. He told staff and friends that he’d seen nine unusual airborne objects. Arnold estimated their speed at 1,700 miles per hour, beyond the capabilities of known aircraft. Newspapers soon contacted Arnold for interviews. The East Oregonian reported his supposed aircraft as “saucer-like”. In a June 26 radio interview, Arnold described them as “something like a pie plate that was cut in half with a sort of a convex triangle in the rear”. Headline writers coined the terms “flying saucer” and “flying disk” (or “disc”) for the story. Arnold later told CBS News that the early coverage “did not quote me properly […] when I described how they flew, I said that they flew like they take a saucer and throw it across the water. Most of the newspapers misunderstood and misquoted that, too. They said that I said that they were saucer-like; I said that they flew in a saucer-like fashion.” The circular shape of typical flying saucers may be due to reporters mistaking Arnold’s “saucer-like” description of motion.

Arnold’s story preceded a wave of hundreds of flying saucer reports. Lieutenant Governor of Idaho Donald S. Whitehead claimed he saw a fast-moving object resembling a meteor around the time of Arnold’s sighting. In early July, head of Air Materiel Command Nathan F. Twining told reporters that “anyone seeing the objects” should contact Wright Field. The next widely publicized report was the sighting by a United Airlines crew on July 4 of nine more disc-like objects pacing their plane over Idaho.

The public was divided on the potential origin of the saucers. Arnold told military intelligence officers he suspected the discs were experimental aircraft, and early newspapers reported Arnold saying, “I don’t know what they were—unless they were guided missiles.” News media speculated on a Soviet origin, and many war veterans connected them to the foo fighters seen during World War II. A Gallup Poll found that 90% of Americans were aware of the saucer stories, and 16 percent believed they were secret military weapons, most likely American. The most common explanation given was some type of illusion or mirage. Less than one percent believed they were alien craft. One report from Seattle, Washington, described a hammer and sickle painted onto a flying disc. The stories spread to other countries, where they were influenced by local political and social concerns. In Europe, which was still recovering from the Second World War, saucers were often reported with rocket-like features. German newspapers reported flying saucers that exploded or had tails of fire. The names for the discs were largely derived from the English “flying saucer” including the French soucoupe volante, Spanish platillo volante, Portuguese disco voador, Swedish flygande tefat, German fliegende Untertasse, and Italian disco volante.

The 1947 sightings peaked in the days after the Fourth of July and declined rapidly through mid-July. Multiple organizations offered $1,000 rewards for hard proof. In the widely reported July 7, 1947, Twin Falls saucer hoax, four teenagers in Idaho fabricated a crashed disc from jukebox parts. On July 8, the Army Air Force base at Roswell, New Mexico, issued a press release saying that they had recovered a “flying disc” from a nearby ranch; the so-called Roswell UFO incident made front-page news. International media covered the military’s announcement of a crashed disc, but within 24 hours were reporting the military’s retraction and explanation that the material was balloon debris. By July 11, the most widely reported story was a North Hollywood resident’s claim that a 30-inch galvanized iron disc containing glass radio tubes had crashed in his garden. Newspapers quoted Fire Battalion Chief Wallace Newcombe’s assessment, “It doesn’t look to me like it could fly.”

The Air Force collected over a hundred reports at Wright Field, now Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Ohio. Air Force General Nathan Twining established Project SAUCER, later renamed Project Sign, the first in a series of UFO investigations by the US Government. Other national governments followed suit. Canada began Project Magnet and the United Kingdom launched the Flying Saucer Working Party in 1950, which attributed saucer reports to meteorological phenomena, astronomical phenomena, misidentification, optical illusions, misconceptions, or hoaxes

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flying_Saucers

item.title: Flying saucer
item.description:
Purported disk-shaped aircraft 🔗

This article discusses the history, description, and cultural impact of “flying saucers,” a term popularized in the late 1940s to describe disc-shaped unidentified flying objects (UFOs). It distinguishes flying saucers from the broader category of UFOs/UAPs and explores their evolution in popular culture.

History 🔗

This section traces the origins and development of the flying saucer phenomenon.

Precursors 🔗

This subsection explores earlier reports of unusual aerial phenomena that predate the term “flying saucer.” These include:

  • Mysterious lights in the sky interpreted as spiritual phenomena in antiquity.
  • 19th-century newspaper reports of massive airships.
  • The 1878 Denison Daily News article describing an object resembling a saucer.
  • “Foo fighters” reported by Allied pilots during World War II.
  • Science fiction stories featuring disc-shaped aircraft, such as Jean de La Hire’s 1908 novel La Roue fulgurante and “The Shaver Mystery” stories in Amazing Stories magazine.
  • Fantasy artwork in pulp magazines depicting flying discs.

Origins 🔗

This subsection details the event that is credited with popularizing the term “flying saucer”:

  • The Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting on June 24, 1947, in Washington State.
  • Arnold’s description of the objects’ motion as “like a saucer skipping across the water.”
  • The media’s coining of the terms “flying saucer” and “flying disc.”
  • The subsequent wave of reported sightings across the United States, including the Flight 105 UFO sighting and the Roswell incident.
  • Early speculation about the objects’ origins, including secret military technology and Soviet aircraft.

Development 🔗

This subsection covers the evolution of the flying saucer concept and its association with extraterrestrial life:

  • The increasing association of flying saucers with extraterrestrial life in the 1950s.
  • Kenneth Arnold’s speculation about an extraterrestrial origin for the objects.
  • The emergence of unusual theories, such as Meade Layne’s speculation about alternate dimensions.
  • The influence of pulp science fiction on beliefs about flying saucers.
  • The rise of the “contactee” movement, with individuals like George Van Tassel and George Adamski claiming to have ridden aboard saucers and received messages from aliens.
  • The development of ufology as a parallel social movement, with figures like Frank Scully, Donald Keyhoe, and Leonard H. Stringfield publishing books and forming UFO investigation groups.
  • The emergence of UFO photography as a subgenre of documentary photography.
  • The eventual decline in popularity of the term “flying saucer” and its replacement by “UFO” and “UAP.”

Description 🔗

This section describes the characteristics and identification of flying saucers.

Identification 🔗

This subsection discusses the identification of reported flying saucers with known phenomena:

  • Experts have identified the majority of UFO reports as misidentifications or hoaxes.
  • Common explanations for saucer sightings include the planet Venus, weather phenomena, balloons, and airborne trash.
  • The US Navy’s Skyhook spy balloon project, which led to numerous misidentified sightings.
  • Psychological studies of why people believe in flying saucers, including Georges Heuyer’s view of the phenomenon as a shared delusion and Michel Monnerie’s psychosocial UFO hypothesis.

Reported sightings 🔗

This subsection summarizes the characteristics of reported flying saucer sightings:

  • Eyewitness descriptions differ in reported appearance, movement, and purpose.
  • Astronomer Donald Howard Menzel’s overview of flying saucers, noting the variety of shapes, sizes, colors, and movements reported.
  • The increasing standardization of alien descriptions over time, with Grey aliens becoming the most reported type of pilot.
  • The influence of popular social and cultural expectations on the details of claimed observations.

Fictional portrayals 🔗

This subsection discusses the portrayal of flying saucers in popular media:

  • Early portrayals emphasized high-speed maneuvers, while later media shifted to slowly hovering discs.
  • Examples of films and television series that feature flying saucers, such as The Flying Saucer, The Day the Earth Stood Still, and The Invaders.

Popular culture 🔗

This section explores the cultural impact of flying saucers.

Literature 🔗

This subsection discusses the appearance of flying saucers in literature:

  • Precursors to modern flying saucers appeared in science fiction literature, including The Shaver Mystery.
  • The emergence of a genre that treated fantastical stories as either true or plausibly true.
  • The use of advertisements to leverage cultural interest in flying saucers.
  • The appearance of aliens and flying discs in 1950s science fiction comics.

Film and television 🔗

This subsection discusses the portrayal of flying saucers in film and television:

  • Many early portrayals of flying saucers linked them to the Cold War.
  • Examples of films that feature flying saucers, such as The Thing from Another World, The Day the Earth Stood Still, and Earth vs. the Flying Saucers.
  • The adaptation of the flying saucer phenomenon by other countries, such as Japan and India.
  • The use of flying saucers in other genres, such as science fiction and comedy.

Architecture 🔗

This subsection discusses the use of flying saucer motifs in architecture:

  • The flying saucer as a symbol of 1950s culture.
  • The use of flying saucer motifs in Googie architecture and Atomic Age décor.
  • Notable flying saucer structures, such as Seattle’s Space Needle and Los Angeles International Airport’s Theme Building.
  • The influence of Googie architecture on the futuristic structures in the cartoon The Jetsons.
  • The use of the flying saucer as an architectural motif by Frank Lloyd Wright.
  • Examples of novelty architecture shaped like flying saucers, such as the Kielce Bus Station in Poland and the Spodek arena in Katowice, Poland.

Broader pop culture 🔗

This subsection discusses the broader cultural impact of flying saucers:

  • Flying saucers were a ubiquitous part of pop culture from 1947 into the mid-1970s.
  • The use of flying disc motifs in toys and other novelties, such as the frisbee and flying saucer candy.
  • The release of novelty songs about flying discs and alien invaders.
  • The appearance of flying saucers in video games, typically as antagonists.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flying_saucers

item.title: Levelland UFO case
item.description:
Levelland UFO Case 🔗

The Levelland UFO case occurred on November 2–3, 1957, around Levelland, Texas. It is considered a notable UFO incident due to the number of witnesses. The US Air Force attributed the sightings to ball lightning or a severe electrical storm.

Reports 🔗

On the evening of November 2, 1957, Pedro Saucedo and Joe Salaz reported a UFO sighting to the Levelland police department, claiming their truck’s engine died when a blue flash of light and a rocket-shaped object approached. Motorist Jim Wheeler reported a large, egg-shaped object blocking the road, causing his vehicle to stall. A married couple reported a bright flash of light that caused their headlights and radio to fail temporarily. Texas Technological College student Newell Wright encountered a 100-foot-long egg-shaped object that caused his car engine to sputter and die. Farmer Frank Williams reported a glowing object that caused his car’s lights and motor to stop. Ronald Martin and James Long also reported similar encounters with a brightly lit object. Sheriff Weir Clem saw a red object moving across the sky, and Fire Chief Ray Jones experienced vehicle malfunctions. The Levelland police department received a total of 15 UFO-related reports during the night.

U.S. Air Force Investigation 🔗

The Levelland sightings were investigated by Project Blue Book. An Air Force sergeant spent seven hours investigating, interviewing Saucedo, Wheeler, and Wright. The Air Force concluded that a severe electrical storm, possibly ball lightning or St. Elmo’s fire, caused the sightings and auto failures, blaming engine failures on wet electrical circuits. Donald H. Menzel agreed with the Air Force explanation, attributing the events to ball lightning.

Ufologists 🔗

James E. McDonald and J. Allen Hynek disputed the Air Force’s explanation, arguing that there was no electrical storm. McDonald testified that ten vehicles were stopped independently within a short area and time. Hynek concurred initially but later recognized the lack of evidence that ball lightning could stop cars and put out headlights. Ufologists also noted that the Air Force investigator did not interview nine of the fifteen witnesses.

Media Coverage 🔗

In March 2002, KDFW aired a report about the Levelland UFO case, interviewing Sheriff Weir Clem’s widow and friends.

See also 🔗

  • Lubbock Lights
  • List of UFO sightings

Further reading 🔗

Lists books and publications for further reading on the Levelland UFO case.

References 🔗

Lists the references cited in the article.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levelland_UFO_case

item.title: Time-traveler UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Time-traveler UFO hypothesis 🔗

The time-traveler hypothesis, also known as chrononaut UFO, future humans, extratempestrial model, and Terminator theory, proposes that unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are humans traveling from the future using advanced technology. This concept has gained recent attention from figures like retired NASA aerospace engineer Larry Lemke, Wisconsin congressman Mike Gallagher, and filmmaker Steven Spielberg. Mainstream scholars consider this hypothesis extremely implausible, and it’s generally viewed as unorthodox even among fringe conspiracy theorists.

Antecedents 🔗

This section explores the origins of the ideas that led to the time-traveler UFO hypothesis.

Origins of time travel speculation 🔗

This subsection traces the concept of time travel from the future to the past back to its literary origins. Pierre Boitard’s 1861 book Paris avant les hommes is credited with introducing the idea, featuring a man sent back to prehistoric Earth. Camille Flammarion’s 1887 novel Lumen also explored the theme of a soul traveling through different historical periods. The section also notes that while time travel is considered physically impossible by most, theoretical research continues to explore its potential feasibility, with scientists like J. Richard Gott and Ronald Mallet speculating on the possibility of future human time travel.

Speculation of future human evolution 🔗

This subsection discusses the history of speculation about the future evolution of mankind. It highlights H.G. Wells’ The Time Machine as an early example of both time travel and speculative evolution. Other authors mentioned include Edgar Rice Burroughs, Olaf Stapledon, Kurt Vonnegut, Stephen Baxter, and Cevdet Mehmet Kösemen. The section also identifies climate change, the technological singularity, space travel, and genetic enhancement as potential factors that could alter human evolution, leading to transhuman and posthuman scenarios.

UFOs and initial explanations 🔗

This subsection provides a brief overview of the history of UFO sightings. It mentions reports of unknown objects in the skies dating back to antiquity, as well as the mystery airship sightings of the 1890s and the Foo fighters and ghost rockets during World War II. The modern UFO era is said to have begun in the summer of 1947, following Kenneth Arnold’s sighting. Initial explanations for these sightings ranged from novel US or Soviet technology to misidentification of mundane objects and mass hysteria. Fringe theories included extraterrestrial or interdimensional origins.

Formation and spread 🔗

This section details the development and popularization of the time-traveler UFO hypothesis.

Implausibility of humanoid aliens 🔗

This subsection addresses the common depiction of aliens as humanoids in contactee and alien abduction folklore. It cites George Gaylord Simpson’s 1964 article The Nonprevalence of Humanoids, which argues that it’s unlikely for extraterrestrial intelligence to exist and even more unlikely for it to be humanoid. The section also mentions Stephen Jay Gould’s thought experiment about rewinding evolution, suggesting that humans would likely not evolve again. Biologist Jack Cohen’s view on the implausibility of Grey aliens evolving a physiology similar to humans is also included.

Modern popularization 🔗

This subsection explores the modern resurgence of the time-traveler hypothesis. It mentions Jacques Vallée’s 1975 book The Invisible College as an early example. Other figures and works mentioned include David S. Anderson, Jenny Randles, James Herbert Brennan, and Philip J. Corso and William J. Birnes’ The Day After Roswell, which reported Hermann Oberth’s belief that the Roswell craft could have been a time machine. The History channel series Ancient Aliens is also mentioned for its episodes exploring the concept. Michael P. Masters’ book Identified Flying Objects and The Extratempestrial Model are highlighted for their in-depth exploration of the hypothesis. Tim Peake and Steven Spielberg are mentioned for their recent public comments on the theory.

In popular culture 🔗

This subsection lists examples of the time-traveler hypothesis in popular culture. It includes the TV series It’s About Time, Gregory Benford’s novel Timescape, David Drake’s novel Birds of Prey, Michael Crichton’s novel Sphere, the TV film Official Denial, the comic book series Blake and Mortimer, the band Yes, Jordan Peele’s movie Nope, and the movie Interstellar.

Terminology and connection to other theories 🔗

This subsection clarifies the terminology used to describe the hypothesis, noting that while Michael P. Masters uses the term “extratempestrial,” the overall idea is often referred to as “the time-traveler hypothesis.” It also discusses the overlap between the time-traveler hypothesis and the interdimensional hypothesis, with figures like John Ventre and Harold E. Puthoff using the terms interchangeably. The section also notes that the time-traveler hypothesis provides an alternative explanation for the absence of future time travelers, similar to how the extraterrestrial hypothesis addresses Fermi’s paradox.

Criticism 🔗

This section presents criticisms of the time-traveler hypothesis. It notes that the hypothesis is considered pseudoscientific. Neil deGrasse Tyson is quoted as calling the hypothesis illogical, and Robert Sheaffer criticizes Michael P. Masters’ work for relying on the belief that time travel is possible. David J. Darling argues that the extraterrestrial and time-travel hypotheses are equally unlikely and unnecessary. Ian Ridpath suggests that Jim Penniston’s claims about time-traveling UFOs may have been influenced by the film Official Denial. Isaac Arthur is mentioned for debunking the concept as presented in Ancient Aliens. Fabio Costa is quoted as saying that time travel requires two doors, one in the future and one in the past, raising the question of where the time machine is.

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics, including Time travel, Posthumanism, Transhumanism, Timeline of the far future, Longtermism, Speculative Evolution, Cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, Psychosocial hypothesis, Interdimensional hypothesis, and Space animal hypothesis.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-traveller_UFO_hypothesis

item.title: Extraterrestrial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Extraterrestrial UFO Hypothesis 🔗

This article discusses the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH), which suggests that some unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are best explained as spacecraft or probes from intelligent extraterrestrial civilizations.

Usage of the Term 🔗

This section traces the use of the term “extraterrestrial hypothesis” in UFO literature. It notes that the term gained traction in the latter half of the 1960s, with early usage attributed to French ufologist Jacques Vallée in his 1966 book. Other figures who used the term in the late 1960s include Aimé Michel, James E. McDonald, and James Harder. Physicist Edward Condon is credited with popularizing the term and its abbreviation “ETH” in 1969 when presenting the findings of the Condon Report. Skeptic Philip J. Klass also used the term in his 1968 book.

Chronology 🔗

This section explores the historical context leading up to the modern ETH. It traces the origins of the idea of extraterrestrial life and visitation to earlier concepts, including Percival Lowell’s theories about Martian canals and ancient Martian civilizations, the science fiction writings of H. G. Wells and Edgar Rice Burroughs, and the works of Emanuel Swedenborg, who linked other worlds to the afterlife. It also mentions Charles Fort, who collected accounts of anomalous aerial phenomena in the early 20th century and theorized about visitors from other worlds. The modern ETH, linking unidentified aircraft to alien life, took root in the late 1940s and 1950s, influenced by pseudoscience and popular culture, and bolstered by unexplained sightings investigated by governments and civilian groups.

Historical Reports of Extraterrestrial Visits 🔗

This section presents examples of early speculation about extraterrestrial visitors. It mentions a French newspaper story from 1864 about the discovery of an alien-like creature inside an egg-shaped structure. It also discusses H. G. Wells’ “The War of the Worlds” (1898), which popularized the idea of Martian visitation and invasion. The section notes a surge in “mystery airship” reports in the late 19th century, with some speculating about Martian origins. It also mentions the influence of comic strips, radio shows, and movies like Buck Rogers and Flash Gordon in popularizing the idea of alien visitation in spaceships. Orson Welles’ 1938 radio broadcast of “The War of the Worlds” caused some public panic.

The 1947 Flying Saucer Wave in America 🔗

This section focuses on the events surrounding the Kenneth Arnold sighting in 1947 and the subsequent “flying saucer” craze. It details Arnold’s initial report of seeing unidentified disk-shaped aircraft near Mount Rainier and his consideration of the possibility of extraterrestrial origins. The section notes the widespread speculation in newspapers about the nature of the “saucers,” including theories about secret military projects, Russian spy devices, hoaxes, optical illusions, and mass hysteria. It mentions Senator Glen Taylor’s comment about wishing the saucers were spaceships from another planet and R. DeWitt Miller’s suggestion that they could be vehicles from Mars or other dimensions. The section also cites journalist Edward R. Murrow’s observation that the ETH did not gain widespread attention until about 18 months after Arnold’s sighting.

Evolution of Public Opinion 🔗

This section examines how public opinion regarding UFOs and the ETH evolved. It mentions the release of the first U.S. poll of public UFO perceptions by Gallup in August 1947, which showed that most people either had no opinion or believed there was a mundane explanation for the sightings. The section also discusses the influence of movies depicting flying saucers and aliens in the early 1950s. It cites a poll published in Popular Science magazine in 1951, which reported that most UFO witnesses believed they had seen a man-made aircraft. By 1957, 25% of Americans were willing to believe in the ETH. A Roper poll in 2002 reported that 56% of respondents thought UFOs were real, with 48% believing that UFOs had visited Earth.

Religion 🔗

This section briefly mentions the connection between UFOs and religion, citing the Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults.

NASA 🔗

This section discusses NASA’s evolving stance on UAPs. In June 2021, NASA Administrator Bill Nelson directed NASA scientists to investigate Unidentified Aerial Phenomenon, exploring the possibility that UAP could represent extraterrestrial technology. NASA scientist Ravi Kopparapu advocates studying UAP with an agnostic approach, involving experts from various fields to collect data and deduce the identity of such UAP. In August 2021, Kopparapu presented a paper supporting ETH.

Private or Government Studies 🔗

This section presents examples of private or government studies that have concluded in favor of the ETH or have had members who disagreed with official conclusions. It mentions a 1948 Top Secret USAF Europe document citing Swedish air intelligence’s conclusion that some UFOs had extraterrestrial origins. It also discusses the USAF Project Sign’s 1948 Top Secret Estimate of the Situation, which concluded that the ETH was the most likely explanation for the most perplexing unexplained cases. The section mentions a secret West German study from 1951 to 1954, headed by Hermann Oberth, which also concluded that UFOs were extraterrestrial. It also discusses the CIA’s internal scientific review of UFOs in the early 1950s, noting that some CIA scientists were seriously considering the ETH. The section mentions extraterrestrial “believers” within Project Blue Book, including Major Dewey Fournet and consultant J. Allen Hynek, who later became a staunch supporter of the ETH. It also cites statements from former CIA Director Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, who urged Congressional action to reduce the dangers from secrecy about unidentified flying objects. The section mentions Greek physicist Paul Santorini’s claim that a 1947 Greek government investigation into the European Ghost rockets concluded that they were extraterrestrial. It also discusses the 1968 Condon Report, noting that many members of the study disagreed with Condon’s methods and biases. The section mentions the 1999 private French COMETA report, which concluded that the hypothesis of extraterrestrial visitors best accounted for the facts. It also discusses Jean-Jacques Velasco, the head of the official French UFO investigation SEPRA, who stated that 14% of the cases studied by SEPRA were ‘utterly inexplicable and extraterrestrial’ in origin.

Critical Responses and Positions of the ETH 🔗

This section presents critical responses to the ETH. It notes that there is no scientific proof to back up assertions of alien encounters. It states that despite ardent believers, no rigorous analysis has ever concluded that various UFO sightings are verifiable evidence for the ETH.

U.S. Military Investigation and Debunkery 🔗

This section discusses the U.S. military’s investigation of UFOs and its efforts to debunk the ETH. It mentions the formation of Project Sign in 1947, the first official U.S. military UFO study. It notes that Project Sign concluded without endorsing any unified explanation for all UFO reports, and the ETH was rejected by USAF Chief of Staff General Hoyt Vandenberg. The section also discusses the CIA’s Robertson Panel, which was organized in 1953 to review the Blue Book’s best evidence and recommend an official policy of public debunkery.

Involvement of Scientists 🔗

This section examines the scientific community’s response to the ETH. It notes that the scientific community has shown very little support for the ETH, largely accepting the explanation that UFO reports are the result of misinterpretations or hoaxes. It mentions Stephen Hawking’s skepticism about the ETH. The section cites Carl Sagan’s observation about the emotional nature of the idea of extraterrestrial visitation and the potential for self-deception. It also quotes Peter A. Sturrock’s statement about the narrow polarization of the UFO debate around the ETH. The section presents the results of a 1973 poll of American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics members, which found that about 10% believed that UFOs were vehicles from outer space. It also presents the results of a 1977 poll of American Astronomical Society members, which asked them to assign probabilities to eight possible explanations for UFOs. The section summarizes the primary scientific arguments against ETH, as outlined by J. Allen Hynek, including the failure of surveillance systems to detect UFOs, gravitational and atmospheric considerations, statistical considerations, the behavior of UFOs and their occupants, the isolation of the UFO phenomenon in time and space, the space unworthiness of UFOs, and the problem of astronomical distances.

Fewer Sightings Despite Camera Phone Technology 🔗

This section discusses the argument that the proliferation of smartphone camera technology has not led to a significant increase in recorded UFO sightings, calling into question the claimed phenomenology of UFOs.

NASA 🔗

This section presents NASA’s official standpoint on the ETH, which is that it lacks empirical evidence. It quotes David Morrison’s statements that no one has ever found a single artifact or any other convincing evidence for alien visits and that no claims of UFOs as being alien craft have any validity.

CIA 🔗

This section mentions the CIA’s organization of the January 1953 Robertson Panel of scientists to debunk the data collected by the Air Force’s Project Blue Book.

Official White 🔗

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_hypothesis

item.title: The Roswell Incident (1980 book)
item.description:
The Roswell Incident (1980 book) 🔗

This entry details the 1980 book The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and William Moore, which significantly contributed to popularizing the Roswell incident.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the Roswell incident, focusing on the events of 1947 and the renewed interest in the story in the late 1970s.

Events of 1947 🔗

This subsection outlines the initial reports of the Roswell incident during the “flying disc craze” of 1947, Kenneth Arnold’s sighting, the Roswell Army Air Field’s initial press release about recovering a crashed disc, and the subsequent retraction stating it was a weather balloon.

Roswell revisited 🔗

This subsection explains how the Roswell story gained traction again in 1978 when retired lieutenant colonel Jesse Marcel claimed in an interview with ufologist Stanton Friedman that the debris he recovered was extraterrestrial.

Authors 🔗

This section provides background information on the authors of the book, Charles Berlitz and William Moore. It mentions Berlitz’s previous success with The Bermuda Triangle and their collaboration on The Philadelphia Experiment: Project Invisibility.

Contents 🔗

This section summarizes the book’s central argument: that an extraterrestrial craft crashed in New Mexico while observing nuclear weapons activity, and the US government engaged in a cover-up. It highlights accounts of debris described as “nothing made on this earth” and mentions witnesses like Bill Brazel, Floyd Proctor, and Walt Whitman Jr. The section also notes the book’s introduction of the idea that the debris shown in photos with Marcel was substituted as part of the cover-up. It also mentions the claim that the military sought to discredit the growing interest in flying saucers. The section also notes that the authors claimed to have interviewed over 90 witnesses, but only a fraction of those accounts appear in the book. The section also notes that the book elevated Marcel’s narrative above that of Cavitt, whose description of the debris contradicted Marcel.

Alien bodies 🔗

This section details the book’s introduction of the story about Barney Barnett and archaeology students encountering wreckage and “alien bodies” on the Plains of San Agustin. It also mentions the conflation of the Roswell incident with the Aztec, New Mexico, UFO incident, a hoaxed flying saucer crash promoted by Frank Scully.

Reception 🔗

This section discusses the reception of the book, noting that critics deemed it “a collection of wild hearsay” and that it “did not make the commercial impact its authors hoped.” It also mentions accusations against Moore regarding the Majestic 12 documents.

Aftermath 🔗

This section mentions Moore’s admission at a 1989 MUFON conference that he had engaged in “disinformation” activities against Paul Bennewitz on behalf of the Air Force Office of Special Investigations.

Modern views 🔗

This section references the 1993 inquiry by the General Accounting Office in response to US congressman Steven Schiff, which led to a 1994 Air Force report concluding that the recovered material was likely debris from Project Mogul, a military surveillance program using high-altitude balloons.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Roswell_Incident_(1980_book)

item.title: Trinity UFO Case
item.description:
Trinity UFO Case 🔗

This article discusses the alleged Trinity UFO case, a story about a crashed unidentified object near the Trinity test site in New Mexico in August 1945. The narrative centers around claims made by José Padilla and Remigio Baca, who, as young boys, reported witnessing the crash and its aftermath.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the Trinity UFO case by referencing the broader history of UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions the Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting, the 1947 flying disc craze, the Roswell incident, and the Aztec, New Mexico crashed saucer hoax. It also introduces Jacques Vallée, a ufologist and author who publicized the Trinity case, noting his involvement in the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind.

The Context 🔗

This section describes the setting of the alleged incident, focusing on the Padilla family’s ranch near the Trinity test site. It details the family’s lifestyle, including Faustino Padilla’s work and José’s responsibilities on the ranch. It also mentions the impact of the Trinity test on the local population, including Inez Padilla’s loss of eyesight. The section touches on the backgrounds of both the Padilla and Baca families, noting their Spanish and Apache heritage.

Claims by Padilla and Baca 🔗

This section outlines the specific claims made by José Padilla and Remigio Baca regarding their alleged encounter with a crashed UFO.

First day 🔗

This subsection details the initial sighting of the crashed object by Padilla and Baca on August 16, 1945. It describes their search for a lost cow, the loud bang they heard, and their discovery of a groove in the ground leading to an “avocado-shaped” object. They report seeing small, insect-like creatures near the object, which they compared to a praying mantis, Jerusalem cricket, and fire ant. The boys estimated the object’s size and described its metallic appearance, as well as the appearance of the creatures.

Third day 🔗

This subsection recounts the boys’ return to the crash site with José Padilla’s father, Faustino Padilla, and Eddie Apodaca, a state police officer. It states that the adults entered the object but were visibly disturbed afterward, warning the boys to remain silent. The boys later returned alone and witnessed soldiers collecting debris.

Fourth day 🔗

This subsection describes a visit to the Padilla family by Sergeant R. Avila, who requested permission to access the property to recover an “experimental weather balloon.” Avila emphasized the need for secrecy and the use of heavy equipment.

The fifth and the following days 🔗

This subsection details the alleged military operation to recover the crashed object. It describes the construction of a road and gate, the arrival of a lowboy trailer, and the use of a crane to lift the object. Padilla and Baca claim to have secretly observed the military’s activities. They also describe how they obtained a “souvenir” from inside the object, a metal piece they named “Tesoro.”

After the recovery 🔗

This section describes the aftermath of the alleged recovery operation. It mentions the removal of the object, the clearing of the crash site, and the hiding of the “Tesoro” by the boys. It also touches on the atmosphere of secrecy and fear in the area, with rumors of government intervention for those who spoke too much about the events. Vallée draws parallels between this case and the Roswell incident.

Publication 🔗

This section details the publication history of the Trinity UFO case. It mentions Ben Moffett’s initial reporting in 2003, the analysis of the “Tesoro” metal piece, Timothy Good’s mention of the incident in his book, and Paola Harris’s awareness of the case.

Criticisms and responses 🔗

This section presents criticisms of the Trinity UFO case, primarily from skeptical writer Brian Dunning, who characterizes the story as a hoax. Dunning cites inconsistencies in the story, such as the claim that Eddie Apodaca was a state trooper at the time of the incident, when he was actually serving in World War II. It also includes responses from Jacques Vallée, who defends the case and addresses the criticisms raised by Douglas Dean Johnson. Vallée acknowledges some inaccuracies in the original reporting but maintains that the core story is valid.

See also 🔗

This section lists related topics, specifically the Roswell incident and the Aztec, New Mexico crashed saucer hoax.

Bibliography 🔗

This section lists the books cited in the article, including Need to Know by Timothy Good and Trinity: The Best-Kept Secret by Jacques Vallée and Paola L. Harris.

References 🔗

This section provides a list of citations used in the article.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trinity_UFO_Case

item.title: Gulf Breeze UFO incident
item.description:
Gulf Breeze UFO Incident 🔗

The Gulf Breeze UFO incident refers to a series of claimed UFO sightings that occurred in Gulf Breeze, Florida, between November 1987 and May 1988. The events gained widespread attention after the Gulf Breeze Sentinel newspaper published photographs purportedly showing a UFO, provided by local contractor Ed Walters.

Events of November 11, 1987 – May 1, 1988 🔗

Ed Walters claimed to have been immobilized by a blue beam on November 11, 1987, after which he took photos of a UFO hovering near his home. He reported multiple subsequent encounters, taking more photos and even videotaping the object. Walters also claimed to have witnessed the craft landing and aliens exiting, communicating with him telepathically in English and Spanish, and even being lifted off the ground by a blue beam. He reported a total of nineteen sightings or encounters. On one occasion, he claimed the UFO leaked a liquid that continued to boil for weeks.

Investigation 🔗

Walters initially provided his photographs to the Gulf Breeze Sentinel anonymously. He later admitted to being the photographer and submitted to a polygraph test, which indicated he believed his photos were real. Walters also claimed to have experienced missing time on three prior occasions and under hypnosis, stated he had been abducted by aliens.

Several individuals investigated the claims. Ray Stanford initially questioned the weather data related to the photos but later conceded they were likely taken on the reported day. Phillip Klass dismissed the photos as inauthentic. Robert Nathan from NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory suggested the images were double exposures or manipulated. Ed Gray, the mayor of Gulf Breeze, also concluded the photos were fake.

Budd Hopkins believed Walters’ claims were genuine, citing his polygraph test and refusal of a book deal. Bruce Maccabee found a good chance the photos were real. Willy Smith from UNICAT suggested a support under the UFO in the photos indicated it was a model.

Eglin Air Force Base, located near Gulf Breeze, reported no unusual activity or radar blips during the alleged sightings. Gulf Breeze’s police chief, Jerry Brown, attributed the sightings to hysteria and misidentification of activity at the base.

Eyewitness Reports 🔗

Following the publication of Walters’ photos, numerous other residents reported sightings in the Gulf Breeze area. These reports described orange glows, beams of light, and oval or oblong crafts. Fenner McConnell and his wife Shirley claimed to have seen a disc-shaped aircraft with no wings. Brenda Pollak, a Gulf Breeze councilwoman, reported seeing an orange light and witnessed Walters taking photos of a UFO at Shoreline Park. Santa Rosa County Commissioner John Broxson also claimed to have seen unusual lights. Other residents, like Art and Mary Hufford, and Jeff Thompson, reported seeing similar objects. A tollbooth operator, Jerry Thompson, reported seeing thirteen pink-lighted objects.

UFO Research Group Response 🔗

Supporters of Walters, particularly within MUFON, viewed the mass sightings as evidence of the phenomena’s authenticity. MUFON’s director, Walter Andrus, considered the Gulf Breeze incident their “best case ever.” Donald Ware, MUFON’s Florida director, believed the aliens wanted the photos to be seen.

CUFOS, founded by J. Allen Hynek, deemed Walters’ photos fake due to inconsistencies in the craft’s windows and waviness suggesting reflection off water. Friends of Walters reportedly described him as a prankster who had planned “the ultimate prank” and noted parallels between his story and Whitley Streiber’s book Communion.

Model Discovered 🔗

In 1990, a model resembling the UFO in Walters’ photos was found in the attic of his former home. The model was made of foam plates and drafting paper. Craig Myers of the Pensacola News Journal reported the discovery and was able to duplicate Walters’ photos using the model. Walters denied any knowledge of the model, claiming it was planted.

The discovery of the model caused division within the UFO community. Supporters claimed it was planted, while others expressed doubt in Walters’ claims. It was also revealed that Walters had received a $200,000 book advance and was offered $450,000 for miniseries rights. Additionally, he had a prior criminal record for forgery and auto theft, for which he received a pardon from Governor Bob Martinez.

Renewed Interest After 1990 🔗

UFO sightings continued at the Pensacola Bay Bridge into 1991. In 1993, a friend of the Walters family admitted to witnessing Ed faking the UFO pictures. Mark Curtis also reported that Walter and his wife had divorced in November 1992, splitting $2.5 million in assets believed to have come from the hoax.

MUFON held its first annual UFO symposium in Pensacola in 1990, which continued for the rest of the decade. The publicity attracted tourists and UFO sightseers, boosting the local economy.

In the Media 🔗

The Gulf Breeze UFO case was featured on Unsolved Mysteries and a TV special called “UFO Cover-UP…Live!”. Eyewitness Shirley McConnell discussed her experience on A Current Affair. Unsolved Mysteries, Inside Edition, and A Current Affair filmed more UFO shows in July 1990.

In a 1994 episode of The X-Files, Fox Mulder mentions the Gulf Breeze UFO photos, stating he knew they were fakes.

Gulf Breeze singer Ken Manning won an award for his song “Gulf Breeze UFO” in 1999.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_Breeze_UFO_incident

item.title: UFO sightings in the Canary Islands
item.description:
UFO Sightings in the Canary Islands 🔗

This is a list of alleged sightings of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) in the Canary Islands. The article has been flagged for needing additional citations, requiring cleanup, and having multiple issues.

Sightings 🔗

This section lists specific dates of reported UFO sightings in the Canary Islands:

  • 1974 – 24 November: A sighting is recorded on this date.
  • 1976 – 22 June: This sighting is notable due to its duration (over 40 minutes), multiple locations (Tenerife, La Palma, La Gomera, Gran Canaria, and a ship at sea), and numerous witnesses (hundreds of people, including civilians and military personnel). Two witnesses reported seeing occupants inside the craft, but this account is considered dubious by Antonio Munaiz, a military judge who wrote the Spanish government report, and Carlos Dolz de Espejo, the lieutenant general of the Air Force at the time. The official report by the Spanish Air Force was declassified in June 1994, with much of its content released earlier in 1977 by journalist and paranormal investigator J.J. Benitez, who used it for a book on UFO cases.
  • 1976 – 19 November: Another sighting is noted on this date.
  • 1979 – 5 March: A final sighting is listed for this date.

See also 🔗

This section contains a link to the “List of reported UFO sightings” Wikipedia page.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article:

  1. A source labeled “Unknown” links to an archived page from the Spanish Ministry of Defence’s virtual library.
  2. A link to the “Biblioteca Virtual del Ministerio de Defensa” (Virtual Library of the Ministry of Defence) from 2012.
  3. Another source labeled “Unknown” links to a page from the Spanish Ministry of Defence’s virtual library.

External links 🔗

This section provides a link to MUFON (Mutual UFO Network) for recent UFO sightings and pictures.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_the_Canary_Islands

item.title: Communication with extraterrestrial intelligence
item.description:
Communication with Extraterrestrial Intelligence (CETI) 🔗

CETI is a branch of SETI (Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence) that focuses on composing and deciphering interstellar messages that could theoretically be understood by another technological civilization. A well-known CETI experiment is the 1974 Arecibo message composed by Frank Drake. The abbreviations CETI and SETI are generic and do not refer to any particular organization like the SETI Institute. CETI research focuses on mathematical languages, pictorial systems (like the Arecibo message), algorithmic communication systems (ACETI), and computational approaches to detecting and deciphering “natural” language communication. Research also addresses how to overcome problems of decipherment in interplanetary communication, similar to the challenges posed by undeciphered writing systems in human communication like Linear A. In 2015, scientists including Douglas Vakoch, David Grinspoon, Seth Shostak, and David Brin discussed active SETI and the potential risks of transmitting messages to extraterrestrials. A statement signed by many in the SETI community emphasized the need for a global discussion before sending any messages.

History 🔗

In the 19th century, speculation about inhabitants of other planets was common, with many believing intelligent beings lived on the Moon, Mars, and/or Venus. Before radio, proposals for signaling extraterrestrials included Carl Friedrich Gauss’s 1820 suggestion to draw a giant Pythagorean triangle on the Siberian tundra and Joseph Johann Littrow’s 1819 idea to use the Sahara as a “blackboard” with trenches filled with water and kerosene to create signals. Astronomers like Franz von Paula Gruithuisen also looked for signs of life, claiming to see cities and agriculture on the Moon and evidence of life on Venus. By the late 1800s, Mars became the focus after Giovanni Schiaparelli reported “canali” (channels) on Mars, which were mistranslated as “canals,” sparking enthusiasm about Martian life. Inventor Charles Cros sought funding for a giant mirror to signal Martians, while Nikola Tesla believed his inventions could be used for interplanetary communication and claimed to have observed extraterrestrial radio signals. The Guzman Prize was created, offering 100,000 francs to the first person to establish interplanetary communication, excluding Mars.

Mathematical and Scientific Languages 🔗

This section covers artificial languages designed for interstellar communication.

Lincos (Lingua cosmica) 🔗

Hans Freudenthal’s Lincos: Design of a Language for Cosmic Intercourse (1960) expands upon Astraglossa to create a general-purpose language derived from basic mathematics and logic symbols. A dictionary resembling Lincos was featured in Carl Sagan’s novel Contact and its film adaptation.

Astraglossa 🔗

Lancelot Hogben’s 1963 essay “Astraglossa” describes a system for combining numbers and operators in a series of short and long pulses, where short pulses represent numbers and trains of long pulses represent symbols for addition, subtraction, etc.

Carl Sagan 🔗

Carl Sagan’s 1985 science fiction novel Contact explores how a message might be constructed for communication with an alien civilization, using prime numbers as a starting point, followed by universal principles and facts of mathematics and science. Sagan also edited a nonfiction book on the subject, and an updated collection of articles was published in 2011.

A Language Based on the Fundamental Facts of Science 🔗

Carl Devito and Richard Oehrle’s 1992 paper, A language based on the fundamental facts of science, describes a language similar in syntax to Astraglossa and Lincos, but which builds its vocabulary around known physical properties.

Busch General-Purpose Binary Language Used in Lone Signal Transmissions 🔗

In 2010, Michael W. Busch created a general-purpose binary language later used in the Lone Signal project to transmit crowdsourced messages to extraterrestrial intelligence (METI). This was followed by an attempt to extend the syntax used in the Lone Signal hailing message to communicate in a way that, while neither mathematical nor strictly logical, was nonetheless understandable given the prior definition of terms and concepts in the Lone Signal hailing message. The Lone Signal project sent messages to Gliese 526 (HD 119850) in the constellation Boötes, with the message sent on July 10, 2013, and expected to arrive in 2031.

Pictorial Messages 🔗

Pictorial communication systems describe fundamental mathematical or physical concepts via simplified diagrams sent as bitmaps. These messages assume the recipient has similar visual capabilities and can understand basic mathematics and geometry. A critique is that they presume a shared understanding of shapes, which may not be the case with a species with substantially different vision.

Pioneer Probes 🔗

Two etched plaques, known as the Pioneer plaques, were included aboard the Pioneer 10 and Pioneer 11 spacecraft when they launched in 1972 and 1973. The plaques depict the location of the Solar System within the galaxy and the Earth within the Solar System, as well as the form of the human body.

Voyager Probes 🔗

Launched in 1977, the Voyager probes carried two golden records that were inscribed with diagrams similar to the Pioneer plaques, depicting the human form, the Solar System, and its location. Also included were recordings of images and sounds from Earth.

Arecibo Message 🔗

The Arecibo message, transmitted in 1974, was a 1,679-pixel bitmap that, when properly arranged into 73 rows and 23 columns, shows the numbers one through ten; the atomic numbers of hydrogen, carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and phosphorus; the formulas for the sugars and bases that make up the nucleotides of DNA; the number of nucleotides in the human genome; the double helix structure of DNA; a simple illustration of a human being and its height; the human population of Earth; a diagram of the Solar System; and an illustration of the Arecibo telescope with its diameter.

Cosmic Call Messages 🔗

The Cosmic Call messages consisted of digital sections – “Rosetta Stone”, a copy of the Arecibo Message, the Bilingual Image Glossary, and the Braastad message – as well as text, audio, video, and other image files submitted for transmission by people around the world. The “Rosetta Stone” was composed by Stéphane Dumas and Yvan Dutil, and represents a multi-page bitmap that builds a vocabulary of symbols representing numbers and mathematical operations. These messages were transmitted in 1999 and 2003 from Evpatoria Planetary Radar in Russia under the scientific guidance of Alexander L. Zaitsev. Richard Braastad coordinated the overall project. Star systems to which the messages were sent include 16 Cyg A, 15 Sge, HD 178428, Gl 777, Hip 4872, HD 245409, 55 Cnc, HD 10307, and 47 UMa.

Multi-Modal Messages 🔗

Teen-Age Message 🔗

The Teen-Age Message, composed by Russian scientists (Zaitsev, Gindilis, Pshenichner, Filippova) and teens, was transmitted from the 70-m dish of Evpatoria Deep Space Center in Ukraine to six star systems resembling that of the Sun on August 29 and September 3 and 4, 2001. The message consists of three parts: a coherent-sounding radio signal with slow Doppler wavelength tuning, analog information representing musical melodies performed on the theremin, and Arecibo-like binary digital information. Star systems to which the message was sent are HD 197076, 47 UMa, 37 Gem, HD 126053, HD 76151, and HD 193664.

Cosmic Call 2 (Cosmic Call 2003) Message 🔗

The Cosmic Call-2 message contained text, images, video, music, the Dutil/Dumas message, a copy of the 1974 Arecibo message, BIG = Bilingual Image Glossary, the AI program Ella, and the Braastad message.

Algorithmic Messages 🔗

Algorithmic communication systems describe a small set of mathematic and logic symbols that form the basis for a rudimentary programming language that the recipient can run on a virtual machine. Advantages include localized communication, forward error correction, and the ability to embed proxy agents within the message.

CosmicOS 🔗

CosmicOS, designed by Paul Fitzpatrick at MIT, describes a virtual machine that is derived from lambda calculus.

Logic Gate Matrices 🔗

Logic Gate Matrices (LGM), developed by Brian McConnell, describes a universal virtual machine that is constructed by connecting coordinates in an n-dimensional space via mathematics and logic operations.

Natural Language Messages 🔗

This research focuses on receiving a signal or message that is either not directed at us (eavesdropping) or one that is in its natural communicative form. Methods are being developed to detect if a signal has structure indicative of an intelligent source, categorize the type of structure detected, and then decipher its content. This structure modeling focuses on the search for generic human and inter-species language universals to devise computational methods by which language may be discriminated from non-language, and core structural syntactic elements of unknown languages may be detected. If a

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication_with_Extraterrestrial_Intelligence
