Natural Language Messages 🔗

This research focuses on detecting and deciphering signals or messages that are either not directed at us (eavesdropping) or are in their natural communicative form. Methods are being developed to detect if a signal has structure indicative of an intelligent source, categorize the type of structure detected, and then decipher its content. This structure modeling focuses on the search for generic human and inter-species language universals to devise computational methods by which language may be discriminated from non-language, and core structural syntactic elements of unknown languages may be detected. John Elliott is a key researcher in this area. A key concept is that human languages conform to a Zipfian distribution, which may also apply to alien languages. Laurance Doyle explains that the slope of a line that represents individual tokens in a stream of tokens may indicate whether the stream contains linguistic or other structured content.

CETI Researchers 🔗

This section lists key individuals involved in CETI research:

  • Frank Drake (SETI Institute): SETI pioneer, composed the Arecibo message.
  • Dr John Elliott: Researches strategies for deciphering ’natural’ language messages, focusing on algorithms to detect intelligent-like structure.
  • Laurence Doyle (SETI Institute): Studies animal communication and develops statistical measures of complexity in animal utterances.
  • Stephane Dumas: Developed Cosmic Call messages and techniques for generating noise-resistant 2-D symbols.
  • Yvan Dutil: Developed Cosmic Call messages with Stephane Dumas.
  • Paul Fitzpatrick (MIT): Developed CosmicOS system based on lambda calculus.
  • Brian McConnell: Developed a framework for algorithmic communication systems (ACETI).
  • Marvin Minsky (MIT AI researcher): Believed aliens may think similarly to humans, permitting communication, and proposed including algorithms in interstellar messages.
  • Carl Sagan: Co-authored the Arecibo message and was heavily involved in SETI.
  • Douglas Vakoch (METI): Editor of Archaeology, Anthropology, and Interstellar Communication.
  • Alexander Zaitsev (IRE, Russia): Composed Teen Age Message and Bilingual Image Glossary and managed transmissions from Evpatoria Planetary Radar.
  • **Michael W

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication_with_extraterrestrial_intelligence

item.title: Alien Planet (2005 TV series)
item.description:
Alien Planet (2005 TV series) 🔗

A 2005 docufiction TV special created for the Discovery Channel, based on Wayne Barlowe’s 1990 book Expedition. It explores the imagined extraterrestrial life of the fictional planet Darwin IV in the style of a nature documentary. It features scientists and science fiction figures discussing Darwin IV as if it had actually been discovered.

Plot 🔗

The Von Braun interstellar spacecraft travels to Darwin IV, 6.5 light-years away. It deploys the Darwin Reconnaissance Orbiter to find landing sites for probes. The first probe, Balboa, explodes during entry. Backup probes Leonardo da Vinci (Leo) and Isaac Newton (Ike) land successfully.

The robotic probes, called Horus Probes, are equipped with inflatable balloons, solar receptors, computers, sensors, and smaller robots. They have limited AI and are programmed with different personalities. Ike is cautious, while Leo is a risk-taker. They are equipped with a holographic message for any sentient life.

The probes encounter various lifeforms, including Arrowtongues, Gyrosprinters, Trunk Suckers, Daggerwrists, and Unths. Ike studies plant life, while Leo goes after big game. A massive storm hits, and Ike launches weather balloons. Leo finds Bladderhorns and attempts to present the holographic message, but is interrupted. Ike encounters Grovebacks, Littoralopes, Skewers, Beach Quills, and Prongheads.

Leo briefly re-establishes contact with Von Braun until a mysterious creature interferes. Ike is ordered to search for Leo. Ike finds a sea that is Amoebic in nature and encounters giant Sea Striders. Ike finds Leo’s last known location, where a Skewer is killed by a spear. Ike finds Leo and the sapient Eosapiens. Ike presents the holographic message to the Eosapiens, but one of them destroys the camera disk, and the Eosapiens attack Ike. The wrecked camera disk records the Eosapiens carrying Ike away.

Commentary from Michio Kaku, Stephen Hawking, Jack Horner, James B. Garvin, and George Lucas is interspersed throughout the special.

Production 🔗

Alien Planet is based on Expedition (1990) by Wayne Barlowe. Barlowe served as one of the executive producers. Scientists and other figures were assembled to comment on the life on Darwin IV. The documentary gives the appearance of the featured scientists having designed Darwin IV and its animals, most of what is shown of the actual planet and its life follows what is described in Expedition.

Unlike Expedition, which is set in the mid-24th century, Alien Planet is set in the near future, and the planet is explored using sophisticated probes. The technology featured is more advanced than present-day technology, but is based on current trends and informed speculation.

Reception 🔗

Dwayne A. Day of The Space Review gave the special a positive review. Some criticism was leveled at the strangeness of the creatures showcased. Day stated that the animals are bizarre and frequently border on the implausible. A review in The Washington Post stated that a few too many of the creatures seem like cartoonish monsters.

See also 🔗

Lists related speculative evolution, similar documentaries, and topics related to astrobiology and xenology.

References 🔗

Citations for reviews and articles related to the production and reception of Alien Planet.

External links 🔗

Links to the IMDb page, archived Discovery Channel page, and the Internet Archive page for Alien Planet.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Planet

item.title: Roswell, Little Green Man
item.description:
Roswell, Little Green Man 🔗

This article provides information about the Roswell, Little Green Man comic book series.

Overview 🔗

Roswell, Little Green Man is a comic book series created by Bill Morrison and published by Bongo Comics. The series received four Eisner Award nominations. It began as a four-part story within Simpsons Comics #19-22 in 1996, and later continued as its own six-issue title. The initial Simpsons Comics story and the first three issues of the Roswell, Little Green Man series, which detail the origin story of Roswell, were collected in the trade paperback Roswell Walks Among Us in 1997.

Inspiration 🔗

Bill Morrison stated that the series was inspired by the Roswell UFO incident and his interest in drawing 1940s vintage cars, fashions, and architecture. He also cited Dave Stevens’ Rocketeer as a major influence.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources used to create the article. These include:

  • An article from The News-Herald about Bill Morrison being featured at a Lincoln Park museum.
  • A listing of 1998 Will Eisner Comic Industry Award nominees from the Comic Book Awards Almanac.
  • An article titled “Twenty Years of Terror” from Comic Book Creator.
  • An interview with Bill Morrison on Neatorama.

External links 🔗

This section provides links to external websites related to the comic book series:

  • Roswell: Little Green Man at Beek’s Books
  • Roswell: Little Green Man at The Simpsons Archive

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roswell,_Little_Green_Man

item.title: UFO sightings in Canada
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings in Canada 🔗

This article presents a compilation of reported UFO sightings in Canada, spanning from the mid-20th century to recent years. It includes details of specific incidents, locations, and any investigations or cultural responses associated with these events.

1951, Gander, Newfoundland 🔗

This section details an incident on February 10, 1951, where a U.S. Navy aircraft flying from Gander, Newfoundland, to Iceland reported a near-collision with a large, orange, circular UFO. The UFO reportedly circled the American aircraft.

1960, Clan Lake, Northwest Territories 🔗

This section recounts a report from June 18, 1960, where a prospector informed the Yellowknife RCMP detachment about a UFO sighting at Clan Lake, 30 miles north of Yellowknife. The prospector and his partner claimed to have seen a hovering object that hit the lake’s surface. The RCMP investigated but found nothing. Chris Rutkowski, a UFOlogist, is mentioned in connection with this incident.

1967, Falcon Lake, Manitoba 🔗

This section focuses on the Falcon Lake Incident, where Stefan Michalak claimed to have been burned by a flying saucer on May 19, 1967, near Falcon Lake, Manitoba. The section mentions grid-like burn marks on Michalak’s chest and T-shirt. Ufologists consider this one of the most documented UFO stories in Canada. Two books about the incident are listed. Skeptic Aaron Sakulich suggests Michalak’s burns were likely caused by an accident related to alcohol consumption, and the story was fabricated to deter other prospectors. The Royal Canadian Mint released a commemorative coin depicting the event.

1967, Shag Harbour, Nova Scotia 🔗

This section describes the Shag Harbour incident, involving the purported crash of a UFO in Shag Harbour, Nova Scotia, in October 1967. The Royal Canadian Mint also released a glow-in-the-dark coin depicting this sighting.

1969, Prince George, British Columbia 🔗

This section details a sighting in Prince George, British Columbia, on January 1, 1969, where three unrelated witnesses reported a strange, round object radiating a yellow-orange light in the sky.

1974, Langenburg, Saskatchewan 🔗

This section recounts the experience of Edwin Fuhr, a farmer from Langenburg, Saskatchewan, who claimed to have seen five saucer-shaped objects hovering near a slough on September 1, 1974. An RCMP report confirmed the presence of five circles matching Fuhr’s description. The Royal Canadian Mint commemorated the event with a silver coin in 2024.

1975–1976, Southern Manitoba 🔗

This section mentions multiple sightings of a red glowing UFO in Southern Manitoba during 1975 and 1976. The UFO was nicknamed “Charlie Redstar.”

1978, Clarenville, Newfoundland and Labrador 🔗

This section describes a UFO sighting in Clarenville, Newfoundland and Labrador, on October 26, 1978, witnessed by twelve individuals. Constable James Blackwood of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police also observed the object. The Royal Canadian Mint released a glow-in-the-dark coin depicting the sighting. A separate sighting in Clarenville in 2016 is also mentioned.

1990, Montreal, Quebec 🔗

This section details a sighting on November 7, 1990, in Montreal, Quebec, where witnesses reported a round, metallic object with lights forming a circle over the Bonaventure Hotel. The phenomenon lasted three hours. The sighting was commemorated on a Royal Canadian Mint coin.

1997, Trail, BC 🔗

This section describes an event on July 1st in Trail, BC, where two women witnessed three small lights above them that quickly took off down the Columbia River.

2010, Harbour Mille, Newfoundland and Labrador 🔗

This section recounts multiple UFO sighting reports in Harbour Mille, Newfoundland and Labrador, on January 25, 2010. Initial reports of a missile launch were retracted, and the French Government denied any military activity. Gerry Byrne, a Member of Parliament, pressed the government for more information.

2014, Kensington, Prince Edward Island 🔗

This section details a sighting by John Sheppard in Kensington, Prince Edward Island, on June 4, 2014. Sheppard captured unusual lights on his cellphone. MUFON confirmed the sighting, and CBC covered the event.

2014, North York, Ontario 🔗

This section describes multiple UFO sighting reports in North York, Ontario, on July 26, 2014. Sarah Chun recorded videos of flashing lights. Toronto Police received several calls. Various explanations were offered, including quadcopters and Chinese lanterns.

Canadian UFO Survey results 🔗

This section summarizes the 2002 Canadian UFO Survey, noting that Toronto had the most sightings, followed by Vancouver and Terrace, B.C. It also mentions that the Canadian Federal Government directs UFO sightings to Chris Rutkowski of Ufology Research of Manitoba. A 2018 study by Ufology Research reported over 1,000 UFO sightings in Canada in 2017.

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related links to people and projects associated with UFOs, including Dan Aykroyd, Stanton T. Friedman, Paul Hellyer, Peter Millman, lists of ufologists and reported UFO sightings, and Projects Magnet and Second Storey.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, providing links to external websites and publications.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_Canada

item.title: First Contact (novelette)
item.description:
First Contact 🔗

“First Contact” is a science fiction novelette written by Murray Leinster, published in Astounding Science Fiction in May 1945. It received a retro Hugo Award for Best Novelette in 1996. The story is notable for its early depiction of a universal translator.

Plot 🔗

The story revolves around the crew of the exploration ship Llanvabon encountering an alien vessel near the Crab Nebula. Both ships are technologically matched and represent their respective civilizations. The central conflict arises from the mutual fear that either ship could trace the other back to their home planet, leading to potential exploitation or destruction.

Communication is established, revealing that the aliens are humanoid bipeds who perceive infrared light and communicate via microwaves. Despite the differences, the crews, particularly a young human named Tommy Dort and his alien counterpart “Buck,” develop a rapport. However, the underlying tension remains due to the strategic implications of revealing their home worlds.

The story reaches a climax when Tommy proposes a solution: a mutual exchange of crews and ships. Each crew would take the other’s ship back to their respective home planets after disabling all tracking equipment. This plan is complicated by the realization that the aliens have independently conceived the same strategy.

The story concludes with the successful exchange, each crew departing in the other’s ship. They remove any identifying information that could lead back to their home worlds. Both sides anticipate technological gains from the exchange and plan to meet again in the future. Tommy expresses optimism about future relations, based on his shared sense of humor with Buck.

Radio Plays 🔗

“First Contact” was adapted into radio plays for Dimension X on September 8, 1951, and for X Minus One on October 6, 1955. The X Minus One version was a condensed adaptation with an altered ending. The story was also performed on Exploring Tomorrow on January 15, 1958.

Style 🔗

The writing style of “First Contact” is considered representative of the Golden Age of science fiction.

Legal Action Against Paramount Pictures 🔗

In 2000, Murray Leinster’s estate filed a lawsuit against Paramount Pictures, alleging trademark infringement related to the film Star Trek: First Contact. The estate claimed ownership of the term “First Contact” and argued that Paramount’s use of the phrase infringed on their trademark. The U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia ruled in favor of Paramount, granting summary judgment and dismissing the suit. The court determined that the term “First Contact” had become generic, describing a common science fiction trope, and lacked the necessary secondary meaning to be protected as a trademark.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Contact_(novelette)

item.title: Dover Demon
item.description:
Dover Demon 🔗

The Dover Demon is a creature reportedly sighted in Dover, Massachusetts, in April 1977.

Sightings 🔗

This section details the reported sightings of the Dover Demon in April 1977. William “Bill” Bartlett, John Baxter, and Abby Brabham, all teenagers at the time, independently reported seeing a strange creature. Bartlett described it as about 4 feet tall with glowing orange eyes and no nose or mouth, with a watermelon-shaped head. Baxter reported a similar sighting on Miller Hill Road, and Brabham claimed to have seen the creature the following night on Springdale Avenue. The teenagers drew sketches of the creature, with Bartlett swearing on a stack of Bibles to the accuracy of his drawing. The locations of the sightings, when plotted on a map, formed a straight line over 2 miles. The sightings became public in May, and a local investigator noted similarities to the creatures in the Kelly–Hopkinsville encounter. The Mutual UFO Network also investigated the sightings.

Possible explanations 🔗

This section explores potential explanations for the Dover Demon sightings. One suggestion is that the creature was a foal or a moose calf. Skeptic Joe Nickell proposes that the creature was likely a snowy owl, citing its size and plumage, which could reflect yellow headlights. The “long spindly arms” could be the partially opened wings of the owl. Police suggested the sightings were a school vacation hoax. Ben Radford suggests the sightings may have been influenced by the release of Star Wars and Close Encounters of the Third Kind in 1977.

In popular culture 🔗

This section outlines the Dover Demon’s appearances in popular culture. It was featured in an episode of the American horror television series Lost Tapes on Animal Planet in 2009. The Dover Demon appears as a character in the comic book series Proof, where it can see into the future, and in The Perhapanauts. It also made appearances in The Pound: Ghouls Night Out and Hack/Slash: Entry Wound. A Dover Demon appears in the webcomic Gunnerkrigg Court. In the manga series Dandadan, an alien known as Dover Demon takes the form of a bipedal crustacean-like alien.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dover_Demon

item.title: Nash-Fortenberry UFO sighting
item.description:
Nash-Fortenberry UFO Sighting 🔗

The Nash-Fortenberry UFO sighting occurred on July 14, 1952, when two commercial pilots, William B. Nash and William H. Fortenberry, reported seeing eight UFOs in a tight echelon formation over Chesapeake Bay in Virginia.

Description 🔗

Two commercial pilots, William B. Nash and William H. Fortenberry, reported observing eight UFOs flying in formation over Chesapeake Bay, Virginia. Ufologists highlight the pilots’ observation allowed for measurements of the objects’ motion and size relative to known landmarks. The sighting was reportedly corroborated by independent ground witnesses. Project Blue Book listed the case as an “unknown.”

Explanations 🔗

Donald Howard Menzel suggested the pilots might have seen distorted ground lights due to haze or fireflies trapped in the cockpit window. Steuart Campbell proposed the sighting was a mirage of Venus.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article:

  1. A NICAP report by Thomas Thulien revisiting the Nash/Fortenberry sighting.
  2. Donald Howard Menzel’s book, The World of Flying Saucers, where he offers naturalistic explanations.
  3. Steuart Campbell’s book, The UFO Mystery Solved, where he suggests the sighting was a mirage of Venus.

Further Reading 🔗

This section lists additional resources for further information:

  • Steuart Campbell’s book, The UFO Mystery Solved.
  • James W. Moseley and Karl T. Pflock’s book, Shockingly Close to the Truth: Confessions of a Grave-Robbing Ufologist.

External Links 🔗

This section provides links to external resources:

  • “The Pilots’ Tale” at Saturday Night Uforia.
  • “We Flew Above Flying Saucers” by William B. Nash and William H. Fortenberry, published in True magazine in 1967.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash-Fortenberry_UFO_sighting

item.title: UFO sightings in Nepal
item.description:
UFO Sightings in Nepal 🔗

This article documents alleged UFO sightings in Nepal.

25 March 1968 🔗

This section details a significant event that occurred around 8:15 pm in Batulechaur, Pokhara. Residents reported witnessing a “blazing object” accompanied by a loud thunderous sound, which appeared to disintegrate over the Kaski region. Following this event, a large metallic disk-shaped object was discovered in a crater in Baltichaur, approximately five miles northeast of Pokhara. Additional fragments of a similar object were found in Talakot and Turepasal. The CIA documented this event. Kevin D. Randle mentions in his book “Moon Dust” that the American embassy in Kathmandu sent a secret message to the 1127th USAF Field Activities Group and the 1006th at Fort Belvoir, requesting full cooperation from the Nepalese government, under the subject “MOON DUST”.

20 March 2020 🔗

This section describes a more recent event in Gandaki province. A bright, “burning” object was observed flying towards Earth, followed by a crashing sound. The Astronomical Society urged people to provide evidence of the sighting.

See also 🔗

This section provides a link to the “List of reported UFO sightings” Wikipedia page.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article:

  1. A CIA “Information Report” documenting the 1968 incident.
  2. An article from the Kathmandu Post titled “How the US kept tabs on UFO sightings and Yeti hunting in Nepal,” referencing the 1968 event.
  3. Kevin D. Randle’s book, “Project Moon Dust,” specifically Chapter 8, which discusses the history of Project Moon Dust.
  4. An article from The Himalayan Times titled “Astronomical society urges people to provide evidence on sighting,” covering the 2020 event.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_Nepal

item.title: Barlowe's Guide to Extraterrestrials
item.description:
Barlowe’s Guide to Extraterrestrials 🔗

Barlowe’s Guide to Extraterrestrials is a science fiction book published in 1979, with a second edition in 1987. The book is authored by artist Wayne Barlowe, with text contributions from Ian Summers and Beth Meacham.

Summary 🔗

This section provides a listing of the extraterrestrial species featured in the book. Each entry includes the alien’s name, the author who created it, and the specific work of science fiction in which the alien appears. Some of the notable aliens included are the Abyormenite from Hal Clement’s Cycle of Fire, the Athshean from Ursula K. Le Guin’s The Word for World Is Forest, the Black Cloud from Fred Hoyle’s The Black Cloud, and the Guild Steersman from Frank Herbert’s Dune Messiah. The list continues with numerous other aliens from a wide range of science fiction novels and stories.

Reception 🔗

This section details the critical reception of Barlowe’s Guide to Extraterrestrials. Wendy Bousfield in Library Journal offered a mixed review, praising the colorful drawings but finding them somewhat static and artificial. She also noted the omission of publication details for the novels from which the aliens were drawn. Claudia J. Morner in School Library Journal gave a positive review, highlighting the colorful drawings and the fold-out size chart. The book was nominated for an American Book Award and the Hugo Award for Best Related Work in 1980.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited within the article. These include the book itself, reviews from Library Journal and School Library Journal, and links to the Hugo Awards website and a Kirkus Reviews article.

External links 🔗

This section provides links to external resources related to Barlowe’s Guide to Extraterrestrials, including its listing on the Internet Speculative Fiction Database and its entry in Open Library.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barlowe%27s_Guide_to_Extraterrestrials

item.title: Pascagoula Abduction
item.description:
Pascagoula Abduction 🔗

The Pascagoula Abduction refers to an alleged UFO sighting and alien abduction that occurred in 1973. Charles Hickson and Calvin Parker claimed to have been abducted and examined by extraterrestrial beings while fishing near the Pascagoula River in Mississippi.

Alleged abduction 🔗

On the evening of October 11, 1973, Charles Hickson and Calvin Parker reported to the Jackson County, Mississippi, sheriff’s office that they experienced an unusual event while fishing on a pier along the Pascagoula River. They described hearing a strange whirring sound and seeing flashing blue lights, followed by the appearance of an oval-shaped object. Hickson and Parker claimed they were paralyzed and then taken aboard the object by three creatures with robotic features and crab-like pincers, where they underwent an examination.

Publicity and later activities 🔗

Following the incident, Charles Hickson engaged in interviews, lectures, and television appearances, including an episode of To Tell The Truth. He also claimed additional encounters with aliens and authored a book titled UFO Contact at Pascagoula. Calvin Parker attended UFO conventions and started a company called “UFO Investigations.”

Charles Hickson died in September 2011.

In 2018, Calvin Parker released his own book, Pascagoula: The Closest Encounter, My Story, providing his full account of the event and its impact on his life.

In June 2019, a historical marker was unveiled at the site of the alleged abduction. Calvin Parker, along with Hickson’s son and family, attended the unveiling.

Calvin Parker died in August 2023.

Skepticism 🔗

Aviation journalist and UFO skeptic Philip J. Klass found discrepancies in Hickson’s story and noted his refusal to take a polygraph exam. Klass concluded that the case was a hoax. Skeptical investigator Joe Nickell questioned Hickson’s behavior and suggested that the alien encounter may have been a hypnagogic “waking dream state.” Nickell also suggested that Parker’s corroboration was due to suggestibility, as he initially claimed to have passed out during the incident.

See also 🔗

This section provides a link to the “List of UFO sightings” for further reading.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited within the article, including news articles, books, and websites.

External links 🔗

This section provides links to external websites related to the Pascagoula Abduction, including information about Calvin Parker’s book, a transcript of an interview with Hickson and Parker, and an article by Joe Nickell.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pascagoula_Abduction

item.title: Alien implants
item.description:
Alien Implants 🔗

Alien implants are physical objects that some people believe are placed in their bodies after being abducted by aliens. These implants are purported to have various capabilities, including telepresence, mind control, and biotelemetry.

History 🔗

The concept of alien implants can be traced back to a 1957 radio show interview with ufologist John Robinson, who recounted a neighbor’s claim of being kidnapped by aliens and controlled by “small earphones.” Betty Andreasson claimed aliens implanted a device in her nose in 1967. Dorothy Wallis made a similar claim in 1983. Authors like Whitley Strieber popularized the idea of alien abductions and associated implants. John E. Mack examined an object given to him by a client who claimed it came out of her nose after an abduction. Roger Leir claimed to have removed alien implants from patients. Skeptic Joe Nickell suggests that supposed alien implants are ordinary materials that become lodged in the body and surrounded by scar tissue. Virgil Priscu stated that there is “No mystery, no implants”.

Popular Culture 🔗

Alien implants, depicted as small needles inserted into victims, first appeared in the 1953 film Invaders from Mars.

See Also 🔗

The article references “matchbox sign”, a similar phenomenon related to delusional parasitosis.

References 🔗

The article cites several sources, including:

  • Peter Rogerson’s article “Fairyland’s Hunters, Part One” in Magonia magazine.
  • Joe Nickell’s book Real-Life X-Files: Investigating the Paranormal.
  • Susan A. Clancy’s book Abducted: How People Come To Believe They Were Kidnapped By Aliens.

External Links 🔗

The article provides links to:

  • “Scientific Analysis of an ‘Alien Implant’” by Susan Blackmore.
  • “Skeptoid #519: Alien Implants” by Brian Dunning.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_implants

item.title: Joe Alien
item.description:
Joe Alien 🔗

Joe Alien is a British comic book character who appeared in strips published by Fleetway Publications. He debuted in the preview issue of the science fiction anthology Wildcat in October 1988. The character’s strip was one of four linked serials in Wildcat and was later briefly featured in Eagle after Wildcat was canceled. Joe Alien is the last survivor of the planet Xgangbe-4 and joins the Wildcat mission to help humanity find a new home, commanding the Wildcat 2 exploration shuttle.

Creation 🔗

Barrie Tomlinson created Joe Alien as part of a new science fiction anthology, Wildcat, for Fleetway Publications. The concept involved linking all five features in the comic to form an overall narrative centered on the spaceship Wildcat. Tomlinson created four lead characters, including Joe Alien, to head exploration teams. Massimo Belardinelli was the initial artist for “Joe Alien,” with Tomlinson praising his ability to bring the story to life.

Publishing history 🔗

Wildcat began publication in October 1988, featuring “Joe Alien” as the color strip. Ron Smith took over as the artist from the third issue. Wildcat was canceled after 12 issues and merged with Eagle in March 1989. “Joe Alien” continued in Eagle for four weeks in May 1989 to complete the story arc and also featured in three episodes of “The Wildcat Complete” anthology. Rebellion Developments purchased the rights to Wildcat in 2016 and announced plans to reprint the contents in collected editions. As of 2025, only “Turbo Jones” and “Loner” have been released.

Plot summary 🔗

Joe Alien joins the Wildcat mission after Turbo Jones realizes Earth is doomed. Joe, the last survivor of Xgangbe-4, possesses vast knowledge stored in an external brain-pack. He is selected for his intelligence and physical attributes. After the Wildcat launches, Joe’s sensors locate a potential new home for the refugees.

He leads the Wildcat Two shuttle to scout Area 17, where his team encounters carnivorous vegetation and a two-headed alien. They discover that the plants are controlled by a mad human astronaut from a 2079 Mars mission, who is now worshipped as a god. Joe brokers an alliance with giant insects to escape and later participates in other expeditions.

Joe shares the story of the Xgangbe’s destruction by the Kargroz and his revenge. He is later chosen to find an alien shapeshifter on board the Wildcat. Joe, along with Jones, Loner, and Magee, is kidnapped by a Gamemaster of the Glarzon race but is released after defeating the Glarzon’s troops.

Reception 🔗

Graham Kibble-White described Joe Alien as “dopily designed.”

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Alien

item.title: A Verdade Sufocada
item.description:
A Verdade Sufocada 🔗

This entry details the book “A Verdade Sufocada” (“The Suffocated Truth”) written by Carlos Alberto Brilhante Ustra, a Brazilian military colonel convicted of torture during Brazil’s military dictatorship (1964-1985). The book presents Ustra’s perspective on the left-wing armed resistance during that period and his experiences as head of DOI-CODI, an agency known for political repression, torture, and murder of the dictatorship’s opponents. The book’s publication faced boycotts, requiring the author’s family to finance its print runs. It gained attention after being quoted by Jair Bolsonaro during Dilma Rousseff’s impeachment vote in 2016 and became a bestseller. However, it has been heavily criticized by historians and sociologists who question its reliability as a historical document.

The book 🔗

This section focuses on the content of “A Verdade Sufocada,” explaining that it presents the military’s version of events during the Brazilian dictatorship, emphasizing attacks by leftist groups. The author’s wife, a historian, collaborated on the book, providing context related to the Cold War.

Criticism 🔗

This section outlines the criticisms leveled against “A Verdade Sufocada.” Luciano Oliveira, a sociology professor, deems the book historically worthless but acknowledges its value as confirmation of the disgracefulness of torture. Neusah Cerveira, a historian, points out the lack of explicit bibliographic citations and describes the book as superficial despite its length and strong title.

Bibliography 🔗

This section lists academic works that reference or analyze “A Verdade Sufocada.” These include studies on persuasive communication as a strategy for controlling collective memory, discursive strategies of perpetrators of the Brazilian military dictatorship, and the portrayal of the left by the right in books written by military personnel involved in repression during the dictatorship. The listed authors are Fernando Cibelli de Castro, Fabricio Fernandes, and Clarissa Grahl dos Santos.

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics and figures, including:

  • Torture Never Again: An organization or movement opposed to torture.
  • List of people killed by and disappeared during the Brazilian military dictatorship: A record of victims of the regime.
  • Securing Sex: A potentially related book or study.
  • Sérgio Paranhos Fleury: A controversial figure associated with repression during the dictatorship.
  • Ternuma: Possibly a military unit or operation.
  • Vladimir Herzog: A journalist whose death under torture became a symbol of resistance against the dictatorship.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited within the article, providing specific details about each source, including authors, titles, publishers, publication dates, and URLs where available. These references support the information presented in the article and allow readers to verify the claims made.

External links 🔗

This section provides a link to the official website/blog associated with the book, maintained by Joseíta Brilhante Ustra, the author’s widow.

item.title: Bill Moore (ufologist)
item.description:
William L. Moore (Ufologist) 🔗

William Leonard Moore, born October 31, 1943, is an author and former UFO researcher who gained prominence from the late 1970s to the late 1980s. He is best known for co-authoring two books with Charles Berlitz, including The Roswell Incident.

Career 🔗

Moore’s interest in UFOs began in his teenage years. He graduated from Thiel College in Greenville, Pennsylvania, in 1965. After teaching language and humanities at various high schools, he became the Arizona state section director of the Mutual UFO Network (MUFON). He then transitioned to a career as a freelance writer.

He co-authored The Philadelphia Experiment - Project Invisibility with Charles Berlitz in 1979, which explored the alleged naval military experiment aboard the USS Eldridge in 1943. In 1980, Moore and Berlitz co-wrote The Roswell Incident, which claimed that the Roswell UFO incident involved the crash of an extraterrestrial spacecraft.

In May 1987, Moore, along with ufologists Jaime Shandera and Stanton Friedman, circulated the Majestic 12 documents, which purported the existence of a high-level policy-making group overseeing UFOs and extraterrestrials.

At a 1989 MUFON conference, Moore admitted to engaging in “disinformation” activities against Paul Bennewitz on behalf of the Air Force Office of Special Investigations.

Critical Reception 🔗

The Philadelphia Experiment - Project Invisibility has been largely dismissed as an unsubstantiated urban myth. The Roswell Incident has been criticized as a collection of hearsay and unwarranted speculation. Critics have also pointed fingers at Moore regarding the fraudulent nature of the Majestic 12 documents.

Books 🔗

  • The Philadelphia Experiment Project Invisibility (1979)
  • The Roswell Incident (1980)

See also 🔗

  • UFO conspiracy theory

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Moore_(ufologist)

item.title: Max Evans (Roswell)
item.description:
Max Evans (Roswell) 🔗

Maxwell “Max” Evans is a fictional character created by Melinda Metz for the Roswell High book series and adapted for the Roswell television series (1999-2002). He is portrayed by Jason Behr in the original series and by Nathan Parsons in the CW reboot. Max is a central character throughout the series, first appearing in the pilot episode.

Fictional character summary 🔗

This section focuses on the TV character, distinguishing it from the Roswell High book version. Max’s backstory reveals that in a previous life, he was Zan, the king of Antar. After Zan’s death, his DNA and human DNA were used to create alien/human hybrids or clones, including Isabel Evans (Vilandra, Zan’s sister), Michael Guerin (Rath, Vilandra’s betrothed), and Tess Harding (Ava, Zan’s bride). These clones were sent to Earth to escape their enemies, particularly Kivar. The craft carrying Max, Isabel, Michael, and Tess crashed in Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947. The U.S. Army initially took the alien pods, but they were rescued and hidden. The clones emerged in 1989, appearing as children. Max and Isabel were adopted by the Evans, while Michael ended up in foster care.

Characteristics 🔗

Max is presented as shy and introverted, a facade necessitated by his hybrid nature. He is a complex character, displaying both timidity and passion. Despite his initial shyness, he emerges as the leader among his friends. He is portrayed as a deep thinker, often spurred to action by his protective instincts. He takes responsibility for his actions and is known for his unique healing powers.

Powers and abilities 🔗

Max possesses molecular manipulation and telekinesis, abilities shared by the other hybrids. His unique power is healing through physical contact, famously used to save Liz Parker in the pilot episode. He also develops the ability to generate a force field. It is suggested that his healing ability can trigger the development of alien powers in those he heals, such as Liz Parker.

Relationship with Liz Parker 🔗

Max’s love for Liz Parker is a central theme. He has been in love with her since childhood but keeps his distance due to his alien identity. He reveals his secret to save her life after she is shot, initiating the main plot of the show. Their connection is portrayed as deep and mysterious, with Liz able to sense when Max is in danger. Their relationship is considered a core aspect of the show.

Recurring themes 🔗

The relationship between Max and Liz is presented as a modern example of forbidden love, with references to Romeo and Juliet. Maria De Luca refers to them as “modern Romeo and Juliet against the world.” The concept of soulmates is also a recurring theme, emphasizing their deep connection and compatibility.

Fictional biography 🔗

Season one 🔗

Max is first seen watching Liz at the Crashdown Café. After Liz is accidentally shot, Max heals her, revealing his alien nature. Liz discovers his secret and becomes his confidante. Max and Liz’s relationship develops, complicated by his secret. Liz breaks up with Kyle Valenti to be with Max. The hybrids search for answers about their origins. Max discovers a fourth alien. Tess Harding arrives, revealed to be another hybrid. Nasedo kidnaps Liz, prompting Max to save her. Max is abducted by the FBI but rescued by Nasedo and Michael. Sheriff Valenti pledges to protect Max, Isabel, and Michael. The ship reveals their past as the Royal Four of Antar, with Tess and Max being married.

Season two 🔗

Max struggles with his role as “reluctant king.” His relationship with Liz is strained. He learns about new powers and responsibilities. The “skins” arrive in Roswell. Max tries to rekindle his relationship with Liz, but she rejects him. A future version of Max warns that their love will cause the end of the world. Max and Tess become friends. Alex dies. Max has a personal crisis and loses his balance. Tess helps him remember his past. Max sleeps with Tess, who becomes pregnant. Max takes responsibility and stays with Tess. Tess mindwarps him into believing the baby is sick. Max and his friends plan to return to Antar. Liz, Maria, and Kyle discover that Tess killed Alex. Max confronts Tess and lets her go to Antar to save the baby. He reunites with Liz and declares his love for her.

Season three 🔗

Max searches for his son. He and Liz rob a convenience store to find the ship. Liz’s parents forbid her from seeing Max. Max discovers Cal Langley, an alien protector. Langley tries to interfere with Max’s search. Max forces Langley to help him find the ship. The ship doesn’t work. Max realizes he almost lost everything, especially Liz. Max encounters Samuel, an autistic child. Max realizes that Liz is his family. Liz develops alien powers. Liz decides to take a break from Roswell. Someone kills Michael’s friend, Monk. Michael discovers that Meta-Chem is tracking him. Max, Michael, and Isabel rescue Valenti. Max sacrifices his life to heal Meris’ husband. Max’s soul is inside Clayton. Clayton assumes Max’s body. Clayton tries to kill Liz. Max takes control and tells Liz to kill him. Liz kills Clayton, and Max is resurrected. Michael becomes the king. Max returns to be the king. Tess returns with Max’s son, Zan. Tess sacrifices herself. Max gives Zan up for adoption. Liz receives visions of the future. The group agrees to flee Roswell. Max proposes to Liz. Max and Liz get married. The group leaves Roswell together.

Jason Behr about his character 🔗

Jason Behr discusses his initial understanding of Max, relating to his search for truth and his place in the world. He highlights the richness of the script and its honest portrayal of relationships and emotions. Behr notes Max’s evolution throughout the show, from being the conscience of the group to learning to allow others to make their own mistakes. He also expresses his open-mindedness about extraterrestrial life.

Reception 🔗

Jason Behr was cast as Max Evans, despite the character’s original description as blond with blue eyes. David Nutter explains that Behr was chosen for his natural talent, humility, calmness, maturity, and wisdom. Melinda Metz, the original books’ writer, approved of the casting choice. Jason Behr won a Young Hollywood Award for his portrayal of Max Evans and received nominations at the Teen Choice Awards and Saturn Awards.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Evans_(Roswell)

item.title: Making Contact A Serious Handbook for Locating and Communicating With Extraterrestrials
item.description:
Making Contact: A Serious Handbook for Locating and Communicating With Extraterrestrials 🔗

Making Contact: A Serious Handbook for Locating and Communicating With Extraterrestrials is a book published in 1998.

Contents 🔗

This section details the book’s subject matter, which encompasses various aspects of close encounters with extraterrestrials. Bill Fawcett, the editor, is quoted stating his belief that the existence of extraterrestrials is “unquestionable.” The book delves into potential signs and symptoms of alien abduction, including burns, tinnitus, a metallic taste, and double vision. Specific locations, such as Area 51 and Mexico City, are identified as places where encounters are more likely to occur.

Reception 🔗

This section is currently empty, indicating a lack of documented critical or public response to the book.

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited within the article. These include:

  1. A Chicago Sun-Times article by Dolores and Roger Flaherty from July 26, 1998, discussing the book.
  2. A Daily Herald article by Hilary Shenfeld from September 22, 1997, which provides details about the book’s content and the author’s perspective.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Making_Contact_(book)
